my return to roblox after years wow how things have changed i don’t even know where to begin at first i was hesitant to return as i’ve heard negative things so i didn’t want to ruin my memory of the fun times i had but they were hella wrong at first i noticed there weren’t any guests which was quite saddening but i get the reasoning so i went to go make an account the amount of usernames that were taken is absurd then all the censorship for even just a number was interesting to say the least but after like a half hour i finally got in the front page pretty much looked the same it didn’t have my classic red r but that’s okay lol i didn’t know what to play as there were tones of games but then i found murder mystery i’m glad murder mystery games were still around so i clicked it at first it was pretty normal lobby spectate and the shop then i went into the back room and figured out you could vote which was pretty neat i don’t remember if they had that before besides that it felt a bit small but was pretty great other people in the lobby were dripped out there was even a coca cola lady which was actually really cool we load in to a game with this hotel type map i got innocent which was expected lol anyways i noticed coins on the ground so i picked those everyone i saw up with out really worrying about the murderer i didn’t realize there were so many hiding spots then i get earraped by this dude with a boombox on his back you think for the hardcore censorship roblox does now they would fix that anyways i heard a gunshot then we loaded back up into the lobby we won d i went to the shop to see what i could buy with my coins then i realized you need to play for awhile just to get a knife i went back to the front page i saw this game called adopt me was on popular so i decided to play it i loaded in to this dope menu they asked me if i want to become a baby or adult so i chose adult cause why not i went into the tutorial and the amount of customization is insane i left my house with this cool animation then a arrow is pointing me to a white wall i go in then there is this beautiful hub lots of stuff to do i was overwhelmed i make it to the middle which i was surrounded with stuff to buy then i got a pop up to buy this and that but a lot of it was robux i felt like i was in the middle of a indian tech scam anyways i make it inside to adopt a child turns out no children were able to be adopted but it didn’t bother me because i was to busy looking at all the cool animations i go back to the front page to realize all the extra details they had in the game now then something horrible happened i went to go see how many tix i had but couldn’t find any i google to see where it was but then they removed it d i thought that was a horrible idea but eh that’s all i played so far and it was pretty good besides all the robux they wanted me to buy i’m gonna try out some old games when i come back on anyways it’s pretty dope

hi i've formatted this for you quickly it's a bit of a wall of text still but it might help people read through it > wow how things have changed i don’t even know where to begin at first i was how do i teach him to be a good sport my son plays roblox one of the games within it is his favorite slap battles he will play it and then will become exceptionally frustrated and will start crying if he's not being successful i've played with him and am terrible i played for half an hour this morning and got slaps in i was becoming frustrated i explained this to him i suggested that when he gets frustrated he should take a break or play a different game he continued playing; until a few minutes ago when he had a bit of a breakdown how do i teach him to be a good sport about these things without simply taking his device away pvp can be very frustrating but at some point you gotta take a break edit thanks to many of you for the suggestions; especially @sir shark

dad of here i have a year old who loves video games and gets extremely frustrated very easy part of it is that he's just got a cocktail of genetic issues he's inherited from me so it's not easy for anyone but i've found two things that seem to work first is more generally a behavioral grounding thing we regularly have him do breathing exercises to help him slow down and calm down it took a while getting to where he can do it regularly and we've still got a ways to go but when he starts getting worked up and frustrated we have him pause whatever he is doing whether it's a video game playing with toys friends chores whatever; and take three deep slow breaths we've even quantified it which actually helps him understand a lot when he's super crazy and out of control that's a normal breathing is around a or but this slow grounding breathing is a he knows that he's not supposed to breathe at a all the time but we tell him to breathe at a to calm down and get control then start breathing normal at a but when he's playing and excited and having fun he can go crazy around or but even when playing if we tell him he's at a he knows that's always too much and he needs to calm down like i said it took some doing to get to where he can do this but he likes numbers and likes to quantify most things numerically so for him this helps a lot second example i'll play games with him and as we do i let him win sometimes and i make a bit of a show when he beats me like oh man i lost you beat me good job acting disappointed but not sad or frustrated and still making sure he sees i'm happy again not upset but then i'll beat him in the game and of course he gets upset so i use it as a deliberate teaching moment like hey you did really good it's okay to be disappointed because we all want to win disappointed is okay but getting mad isn't instead tell the other person things like good job you beat me i'll get you next time and then you practice and get better and better after trying to tell him then i show him by letting him beat me again and i make another show of disappointment with that exaggerated oh man you got me again but making sure to laugh and show him i'm still having fun then actually pointing out see i lost but i didn't get upset i'm telling you good job and giving you a high five and we're still having fun trying to teach and point out the example sometimes i do something similar with single player games been playing some rogue legacy lately when i get a chance and i took time to point out to him that i get disappointed sometimes with dying which happens a lot in the game being a rogue like and all so i try to be an example letting him know it's okay to be disappointed but not to get mad again occasionally making a show of it for his sake; oh man i died again but that's okay i'll just try again and get better and better that sort of thing making sure to teach actually give an alternative behavior instead of a flat no don't do this thing nobody especially kids do well just being told don't do x but if they're given an alternative it generally always works better instead of a don't it's a try this instead for both the whole breathing and sportsmanship thing being told calm down stop that behaviour doesn't usually work but do this behavior instead works more often but full disclosure i'm not perfect at any of this and kids aren't obedient it never works perfect and sometimes it just ends up with everyone upset and in thier rooms for some needed quiet time that's just parenting edit wow this got a lot more attention than i thought it would i just hope it helps a few people out there every kid is different and this might not work with all kids but hopefully it's given a few parents some ideas parenting is hard so good luck to all you gaming parents who see this

explain hes not expected to win that its the experience of losing that makes the will to suceed become a reality as the saying goes practise makes perfect failure is a stone in the road to perfecting your skills and the path you pave will be difficult but overcoming your task will be rewarding anger is just an emotion and emotions can be controlled same as a games character can be hope it helps he wants to beat it beat your emotions first and take deeps breaths and continue sometimes a minute pause an try again or just try another day its what i do

i teach my son that the emotions are not the problem it’s how he expresses them emotions are normal but yelling hitting pounding etc are not good ways to express frustration teach techniques such as breathing squeezing stress balls rubber band on the wrist etc there isn’t a one size fit all trick it’s going to depend on your kid other than that it’s about emulation kids emulate what they see and hear figure out where your kid learned this behavior and address that my kid blames me and rightfully so when he was younger i did have bad anger control it’s something i’ve fixed for myself and i share that with him and let him see that finally redirect to another activity can help as well i tell me kid that the point of games is to have fun if you’re not having fun play something else or do something else roblox has plenty of games that don’t require pvp

my kids would get angry at video games when they kept losing but i had to sit down with them one time when they got really angry over roblox i dealt with anger issues growing up and used to get super upset when i lost especially when i was playing dota back in highschool but because of dota i learned to lose i taught them that it’s part of the game we can’t always be immediately good or guarantee a victory that losing isn’t always the end to learn how they lost why they lost what they can do to do better i taught them that losing was part of the experience there’s never a guarantee you’ll win i had to explain to them that even dad loses his matches someone they look up to once i told them how i deal with losing they started to apply that in their gaming it’s really about letting them know that even you lose games but the most important part is to show them how you deal with it

i know you don't want to just take it away but if your son isn't old enough to internalize what it means to be a good sport then it's still a completely reasonable option for you as a parent still teaches him consequences until he can have more mature conversations

a lesson i learned early when getting frustrated in magic was that especially in pvp games someone has to lose that means at least half the time or more it will be you that is losing if you can’t learn to be okay with losing the game half the time and still having fun with it you shouldn’t play because you’re just setting yourself up for a bad time

my kid got like this playing pvp games in roblox the first time he got mad i talked to him and explained that is like this sometimes you loose you win its normal the second time it happened i told him we play games to have a good time if a game is making you this angry its not worth playing the third time he got banned for one day for typing something in chat and i grounded him for month and no roblox and had a real serious kind of angry talk with him its been months now and he doesnt play roblox anymore unless is with a friend from school but no pvp games i talk to him regularly when he is playing to see if is having a good time and check what games he is playing sometimes takes a while for them to understand i explained a lot of variables with pvp games like skill time ping and in roblox specially age since we have years old kid playing against and older people a game is not worth you getting angry to this point

taking a break is the easiest way out make it like a rule to take a break after every game no matter what win or lose this will allow them to have time to cool off if they're upset if they're happy it's fine to take a break anyway for myself i learned to appreciate and congratulate the other person and that helps with the frustration it just removes most of that feeling and if the winner is being a good sport i don't even feel frustrated at all
give him a fromsoft game i recommend sekiro you'll get destroyed if you don't keep your cool and stay focused in sekiro if he knows any better he'll learn to do just that
that's when you take the game away if they can't learn to let it just be what it is then take it away for a little while especially if its resulting in tantrums

i used to tell my son if he can't control himself i'm taking the game from him soon as he yelled i'd look at him and just walk over and turn the game off if it kept up i'd do the same thing if he was being a bad teammate but not for being a bad player now he's when he plays and someone yells hacker he calmly tells his teammates they are better than them and that they have to play better to win if people are raging he tells them that being mad isn't helping the team and that they have to focus

in person competitive activities are where kids learn to be good sports as being a good sport in front of your peers is much more rewarding than being a good sport anonymously or with your parents another option would be to enable voice chat and allow your child to be flamed and humiliated by his opponents but that seems needlessly cruel to everyone involved

as someone that avoids pvp of any kind because my short fuse with cussing at the game can't always help it i stay away from stuff that i have a short fuse for competitive gaming is one of those things i do great generally but the one time i die in a stupid way whether just a busted powerful one shot or my own stupid decision or mistakes i end up cursing at the game it's not worth upsetting family with the shouting i don't chat with random people in games except to greet or to toss out a gg good game regardless of how i felt after the match frustration isn't a bad thing it's just whether he stifles acting out because of it frustration is a natural byproduct of a competitive spirit and should be a motivator not a detriment i played games with my nephew constantly as he grew up and he saw me get irate at games all the time getting irked is fine but getting so upset that you're not thinking about how to do better is counterproductive just try to drill into his mind that playing against other people tends to have someone lose but there's always more people to play against and always more games to play it seems like pvp related stuff is all the rage and as someone that grew up with unreal tournament and quake and such i totally get it but the added energy drain of dealing with other players online is not my cup of tea anymore best friend and his daughter play roblox games constantly a plethora of them on there i'd recommend switching it up to other games in roblox when the frustration hits and equate playing a different roblox thing with taking five or a walk to calm down after getting upset at something

explain to him that what he is doing is called “tilting” and it’s a strategy used to beat other people making someone else frustrated in some way will make them tilted and they’ll mess up more it’s why stupid tricks work sometimes and why gimmicks work too not sure for roblox just in general so one strategy to win a game is to make the opponent tilt talk to him about things that aggravate him that others do then discuss how it makes him play worse then how he can incorporate those things to frustrate the opponent getting tilted isn’t a problem it’s the attitude you have toward it if an opponent pisses you off during a game that’s ok after the game laugh about it and say “that thing you did had me so mad good job great game ” there’s tons of strategies and methods in dealing with this though it’s a rabbit hole lol

poor video game loser my entire life when i'm winning the world is great and i'm feeling great when i lose i not only lost the game by also my whole shit so on the one hand i recognize the behavior and that it isn't good none of the shit matters in minutes but controlling the melt down is very difficult potential solutions have him play with friends i wouldn't be caught dead melting down in front of friends and now that i'm older i won't melt down in front of anyone at all it's embarassing plus playing with friends opens up certain ball busting commentary which is fun if it goes both ways and distracts from the melt down allow one outburst that serves as a warning a second outburst triggers an immediate minute cool down for that game only you have to be strong and stick to the rule no bargaining condition the behavior away medication not saying you should give your kid drugs but somehow i have the power to understand why i am losing if i have smoked weed and can calmly make adjustments to my playing i am certain there are better prescriptions that do a better job your results may vary sometimes games or other players really do cheat must accept the things that are out of your control

diet soda is one form of self control as i said processed added sugar is a real problem in the united states it's literally in everything unless you specifically buy something that uses a different sweetener most people live with being diabetic for years without even realizing it the only early symptoms most people get are frequent thirst urination which they'll often supplement with a sugary drink and slightly worse vision which can just be attributed to well i guess i'm getting older and fix it with vision correction the brain needs sugar and a lot of it to do its thing we're all hard wired to crave it for this reasoning but evolution doesn't progress as fast as our society has which is why survival traits our bodies employ are counterintuitive to a comfy sedentary lifestyle it's why our bodies still hoard fat and still try to hoard sugar every time you consume it the neuropathways in the brain are reinforced to make you want more of it eating sugar releases dopamine in a similar way to taking a hit of cocaine causes it to be released the big difference here is that doing cocaine the first time and subsequent times is a choice because of the prevalance of sugar in foods and the way our society rewards children with candy and desserts people are getting addicted to it from the time they're babies and it's not really their fault because they're too young to know moderatation and our society as a whole is really only starting to scrutinize the amount of sugar we ingest so yeah if someone wants to drink a can of diet mountain dew to prevent them from going ham on a chocolate cake or some shit let them you simply can't go cold turkey on sugar anyway since your body does have a need for it so trying to undermine the addiction argument is a pretty shitty thing to do god could you imagine if heroin was necessary to stay alive and you were telling people stop blaming your addiction because you don't have to do that much heroin

there is some intuition in the sense of like 'ok this pokemon looks like a strong special attacker so i'll raise my special defense to tank this hit' or 'this pokemon seems like it probably has ground attacks so i'll switch to a flying pokemon' i suppose that's the strongest point in my view i think but it's not like intuition on the level of a fighting game like smash bros for example in which there's this constant like unconscious judgment of what the next right move is on a moment to moment basis i suppose i dont mean to imply that pokemon games *should* or should be expected to have that intuition style of gameplay; i just mean to list it as one of the things i find enjoyable in games in general and that if a game lacks deep strategy and compelling narrative then to me reaction time intuition seems like the only thing that can compensate >as for motivating narrative it's a pokémon game the narrative is to become the very best and become campion as ever i dont see that as inherently being a motivating narrative; why care about becoming the champion if it doesnt feel like the odds are stacked against the playable character the player themselves if considering the playable character as a self insert becoming the champion seems so easy and inevitable that it feels like there's nothing to 'prove' in a sense like challenging a pre school to a spelling bee which i suppose wouldnt necessarily be bad if the playable character didnt seem like such a self insert i mean give the playable character a personality and make them look excited about becoming champion look disheartened when they encounter set backs and so on and sometimes that is enough motivation for the player to want to act as a guiding force even if the game is very easy i believe i think the game little misfortune is a good example of this in which it seems easy and inevitable to 'win' but often still enjoyable to play because the player just wants to guide the playable character forward >these are kids games how much deep strategy do you want for a game that has a bunch of animals that can blast thunder out of their backsides as much as possible if it's too difficult have an option in the main menu to artificially limit the opponent's stats but not artificially limit the player's potential like if a child is discouraged playing chess against their parent dont give up on chess and resort to checkers just handicap the parent by having them start with less pieces until the child is able to win enough for it to be engaging

think of computer memory like a big chalkboard that can be used to remember stuff for later once you're done with some information you have to erase it to free up that space for something else if you forget to erase it that's a memory leak say you write down the player's shoe size every time they walk into a shoe store and then you forget to free that memory up when they leave you'll be writing it down *again* every time they walk back in there'll be less and less room on the board for other stuff and eventually you run out of space and the whole thing crashes restarting the game erases everything on the chalkboard and starts fresh

for parents who are struggling to keep their sanity and their kids busy for parents who are struggling to keep their sanity and their kids busy i'd recommend introducing them to roblox roblox is a video game that can be played on phones tablets or on the computer it is very kid friendly and oriented and has good parental controls and it helps with kids' creativity imagination social skills grammar spelling and more there are lots of worlds kids can explore there including going to a waterpark delivering pizza at a pizza place baking cookies even going to school enough to keep them busy and entertained for hours if you need the time both me and my wife work from home often and we don't have care right now because of the coronavirus and roblox has been a blessing keeping our kid busy when we need our time she started playing just before all the covid events happened and this really saved us she even started her own [youtube channel] which inspired other kids in her class to join and play the game and she can play with her classmates and have playdates on roblox instead of in the real life you can show those vids to your kids if you want them to see what roblox is like and how fun it can be also it's a game parents and kids can enjoy playing together sometimes too so anyway hopefully this helps parents in similar situation

we're having similar struggles we don't allow our ten year old son to play roblox or fortnite or have a smartphone or have tik tok but it's pretty much all over the place even for th graders my son doesn't have direct access to any of it but he's exposed all the time another issue we've noticed is that most kids don't want to play or be outside unless it's for sports practice we've had a lot of nice weather the past few weeks and all my son and his friends do is play inside they all go to one kid's house because they have a finished basement with every video game device and multiple ipads they at least have been into playing beyblades which is better than constant screens still though i'm disheartened that they never want to *move their bodies* we have a large backyard and an official soccer goal what group of kids wouldn't enjoy yards worth of flat greenspace with a soccer goal and our trampoline i hate becoming that aging curmudgeon of a parent but i don't think it's healthy the direction our society is heading in regards to constant screen time but i guess that's a different topic if i were you i would try to plan the hangouts more constructively but in our experience they'll just decide to go to someone else's house if they can't do what they want

personally i just rememeber how i was at that age my parents didn't get youtube as it was just starting when i was a preteen anime certain games like final fantasy x that had some suggestive scenes etc and i just ended up sneaking it so they had absolutely no control over when i was consuming or going over to friends who were allowed it all the way back to when i was little and wasn't allowed to watch power rangers for the violence so i sneakily watched it instead porn blocks and strictly nothing with any suggestive scenes just meant that my friends and i ended up huddled around a library copy of clan of the cave bear a great book but having a brutal rape scene being our first depiction of sex written or visual at wasn't great basically kids will always find a way trying to dam the river often ends up in the dam breaking better to just try and channel the flow for example i asked my parents to let me get a tattoo at and they could have a say on it my mom was open to it as she knew i'd otherwise do it without their input on size placement image my dad just said no and that there was no way i'd be able to i had a palm sized tattoo on my ribs by the end of the weekend overall i think being very strict just breeds habits of lies and sneaky behavior anecdotally the kids i saw with super strict parents like mine acted out more once we could and just ended up lying more and having a worse relationship with parents as teens+new adults there was definitely a happy medium with some boundaries and rules but not always being on the stricter end of every situation too few boundaries also had issues in today's world kids are being brought into a different society than we were technology and screens are going to be a big part of that no screens at all during the week that's strict by anyone's standards an argument could be made that it could stunt their proficiency and intuitiveness with certain tech later on as is being proven by toddlers using tablets having earlier fine motor control and pattern recognition bbc documentary there are a bunch of studies and articles touting the positives of screens in moderation as tools for example my almost yo has coding apps for kids that he's allowed to play outside normal screen time vilifying screens and the virtual world is frankly reductionist; it's far more grey and nuanced than your comments portray now for roblox itself you call it stupid and that you admittedly don't get it that is you putting your judgement of its value over your child's its sheer popularity shows its entertainment value i don't get why my son likes some of the games he does but heck that's his free time and his choice to spend it how he likes we bond over watching him play together and keep an open line of communication skills that i don't **have** to watch every second because we've established what's not good content for him to play so he's come to me twice and said something weird came up like a jump scare game and he checks with me and we evaluate together same with youtube whenever he wants to play a new game in roblox we look through it together chat with nonfriends is turned off and we've never had an issue beyond the jump scare games touch wood and even the jump scare doors game we just play together and he watches me play and helps so we're laughing and joking as we play i love horror movies always have so i get his draw to the adrenaline of jump scares we just have open dialogues about what's appropriate same as watching harry potter and he knows there are more but we're waiting to watch them until he's older all of that to say what you express as fact is actually opinion as clearly i have some different ones and barring some of the research about the effects of screens on kis everything i've said is largely opinion based so maybe widen your point of view from stating opinions as facts and judging from there

just going to say when i was i was not allowed to have a myspace for what i assume are the same reasons you don’t want your child playing roblox and while i understand why they did it and even understood then it didn’t stop me and didn’t stop any of my friends what i would instead recommend is making sure your kid understands what to avoid and how to stay safe online at that age kids are exposed to so much that you cannot control for example i was in th grade when kids started showing each other girls cup i didn’t go out of my way to see that but kids will just show it to you at school and unfortunately you can’t protect them from that crap forever but you can help them understand how to keep themselves safe and that they can always go to you if there’s a situation they are uncomfortable with in my tween life i definitely did not feel comfortable telling my parents situations like that probably because i didn’t want to be lectured on why i should have either picked better friends or whatever the situation was but otherwise back to your question i would say in that situation you can try to come in and just redirect the group to some other fun activity a parent coming in and getting everyone excited about a trampoline or something might come off embarrassing to a kid that age but they still end up having a ton of fun once they’re out there

this is not a new problem even though the internet is definitely scary as parents anecdotally i was in the early the nineties and my parents were adamant about no tvs and by default no video games during my whole childhood because they had a zero tv screen rule at home i became obsessed with tv haha i would do anything to secretly watch tv at my friends house and i would watch the worst shows now as an adult i still have terrible taste in tv whereas most of my friends who were allowed tv as kids barely watch it as adults this experience taught be a lot about parenting being too restrictive can have the opposite desired effect like others are saying i think it’s good to have good communication with your child about safety and supervision over restriction in the real world there are screens and they will ultimately be exposed so it’s important to teach healthy balance

it can be tough when you're trying to encourage a variety of activities during a playdate but the allure of a game like roblox is strong especially for tweens here's an idea for next time   you could have a chat with your tween beforehand and explain the plan for the day let her know that while roblox isn't an option you're open to suggestions for other activities that she and her friends might enjoy this way she's part of the decision making process   you can also provide alternatives like arts and crafts outdoor games or a movie night sometimes offering a bit of structure can help ensure that there's a balance between screen time and more interactive activities   ultimately it's about finding a middle ground where everyone has fun and your tween still gets to hang out with her friends without feeling left out

i want to reiterate that all of this is just my opinion there’s no perfect way to parent and i could be totally wrong also every kid is different and the way to parent them is usually just as complex your feelings are totally valid it’s a tough and really scary world out there i was given unrestricted access to the internet at a very young age and while i’m a decently normal individual there were definitely things i shouldn’t have seen i don’t think you’re wrong i would just hate to see a negative relationship form out of you trying your best to be a good parent we had two boys when i was in school who weren’t allowed to watch most things that were popular at the time most kids thought they were weird and completely alienated them over it it had a negative impact on one of them also in your defense think of this as a way to bond with your child even if you still say no you can talk to your child about why hear her thoughts on the matter as well maybe she only wants to play because of peers maybe she just wants a further explanation maybe it’s none of the above but communication is key this is an age kids really become independent and won’t just accept a “because i said so” as easily as talking it out whatever you decide to do just step into it with the want to understand so you can be a better more informed parent for your child’s needs

its not that there aren’t good games or wholesome fun to be had on roblox it’s that the platform itself is a bit of a wilderness where kids can just wander into games “experiences” that are based on a scary or inappropriate concept there are many *games* within roblox that are fun and conceptually “safe” — a cute one where you run around collecting cats or a funny one where you are a cat and you run around knocking things down or an elaborate fairy princess world where you can fly and have your own apartment but then your kid can exit that game and walk right into one where you’re being stalked by screaming jump scares or viewing totally age inappropriate memes or images popping up there’s also in game chat with other players the chat filters can be gotten around with creative spelling so kids can still be exposed to concepts or words they shouldn’t be learning about reading yet and clearly people can be on there targeting kids or attempting to groom them not good stuff — a parent who admittedly plays roblox with their slightly older kids

ok this sounds much more rounded out than previous info and does change my response so thank you not allowing roblox then is just a limit you're going to have to accept will cause friction for your daughter and should be defensible objectively and not just because you don't understand the appeal if you still think it's not safe then that's that safety comes first and as a parent it's your barometer that matters and no one else's but some of the other comments about its value make it seems like those subjective judgements went into the mental arithmetic to bar it granted if my son had a sleepover and it was hours of screens i'd question it too unless they were all laughing and joking or playing together because yes too much screen time can abaolutely be detrimental the reason i chose to comment was more surrounding the attitude to screens and their place in society in the next decades but frankly as long as your daughter is otherwise given freedoms appropriate for her age so as not to create other behavioral issues the rest is up to your discretion side note i agree about fnaf for anyone under about unless the kid is very very mature for their age that game disturbs **me** and i've watched way too much of the disturbing movie iceberg than is healthy

i just got my year old a smart phone most of his class has them too we recently had a situation where he was walking the dog and went much further than we assumed he would he was having fun and was gone for hours i was in full blown panic mode he’s a responsible kid and had no idea that i wouldn’t be okay with how far he went but it was hours of pure torture for me we called the police the neighbors were all driving around looking for him i walked for miles screaming his name he came back home and i just cried and cried then i turned to my husband and said “we’re getting him a phone now ” we have parental controls on the phone and firewalls in the house from pm to pm the next day he cannot use any app except for text and calls and he is restricted to only hour of youtube a day so far it has been a positive experience and he still rides his bike plays with the neighbor kids last night he played trains with his younger brothers even though he had full access to his phone we’ve had many conversations about the dangers of having a phone access to the internet addiction to pornography and addiction to using the phone so far it’s going well and i’m more comfortable with him walking home from school and stuff

i'm i grew up on the massive tech curve including uncontrolled internet and gaming access i graduated highschool in i don't let my son play roblox and i work to ensure he gets a healthier childhood than i got i don't think trying to keep kids kids is wrong i remember being and visiting the home of a boy i had a crush on after school his mom was home with his younger siblings she was a trad wife in a nice home we were trying to find a movie to watch in the living room and he said he wasn't allowed to watch pg at years old his mom made him home made lunches with nuts and no processed foods that stayed with me my entire life i thought it was really wonderful at years old that he was allowed to be a kid he was one of the most internally secure and chill people i ever met i want my son to grow up as close to that as i can i think a lot of us do just because kids are maturing faster today as i did doesn't mean we have to continue the cycle and not fight it progression a parents job is to protect our children even if it's us protecting them from current cultural norms that force them to grow up too fast

i remember being and playing a lot of games with chat features and potentially inappropriate material i'm now my mom has generally been lenient about things like that from a child's perspective i *remember* all the inappropriate things i was seeing and i was aware of them being not appropriate at the time becoming aware of a thing like sexuality or observing our own others' developing bodies in a sexual way is developmentally appropriate for a year old what i think my mom could've done better was talking to me about things like our bodies consent stranger danger etc how you guide a child *through* the fact that the internet can be a weird inappropriate place is part of parenting imo being restrictive would have only delayed my exposure not prevented it instead i learned how to be smart and safe about using the internet for the screen time hours is a way tiny amount of time for a weekend if homework sports and chores are done i don't see why kids need to be policed on weekends the same as if my boss told me i can't watch tv on weekends lol i'm not at work that time is mine kids deserve their own unmonitored and uninterrupted time once their responsibilities are done otherwise they're basically working to please adults days a week and has always seemed unethical to me

i have a seven year old with adhd and autisim and let me tell you no i don't think roblox is appropriate there are many games some are very innocent and ona tablet where they can't talk to anyone okay but you have to know which games are okay and know that a lot of adults play on those games and to me it's creepy i don't let my son play them anymore and won't again because some of the stuff on there is not okay honestly i barely let my kids ply minecraft and usually with me my yr old gets to play without me right there but for a seven year old just know they are going to be exposed to a lot of language and want to buy a ton of stuff i personally think they are awful for small kids do yourself a favor and just don't my kid doesn't even ask to play anymore and there are times i will play with him but when it comes to anything online just teaching your kid what to look for is not enough because with mics and instant messages your kid will hear things that don't sound bad but are down right evil i've heard older teenagers say some evil things that sound innocent to a kid but are downright evil and grooming behavior minecraft i tend to be okay with but roblox absolutely not and for minecraft i would stick to closed servers where they can play with friends or just an adventure instead of with a ton of people online you need to be so careful with anything online when it comes to your kids because you will have grown ass adults telling small children to end their lives and other awful evil things and if you aren't right there listening and paying attention you might not catch it it is only because i am a strict mom and tend to be over protective with my yr old i caught that stuff i don't let either of my kids ply roblox and never will again

it's been great for my son he's ten now but has been playing roblox since probably six or so during the pandemic it was especially great because it was an easy way for he and his friends from school to get together for zoom playdates they still do that sometimes even now that school has been back in person for a while and friends that he has who have moved away he's been able to keep up with them that way as well i was careful to watch the games that he played initially and we played a lot of games together as well some were quite fun while others were not that entertaining for me but he enjoyed them and we got a lot of good bonding time playing them together there are a wide variety of games some of which are more traditional and others of which allow you to roleplay in various worlds working in a hospital on a submarine etc he used these games the way i used to use fisher price little people very imaginative play developing narrative etc on the whole i think roblox has been a really good experience for him he's had a lot of fun playing it and we've had a lot of fun playing it together as well but it is hardly essential so if you decide it's not right for your family then there's certainly nothing wrong with that

we got roblox for our kid when she was as her cousins were playing it and it seemed fine i locked down the chat functions so she couldn't talk to strangers and she would game with friends while they chatted on kids messenger seemed great right i didn't understand that it's an open platform with pretty much no limits on what kind of games people want to make she kept talking about things that were making me uncomfortable but not terrible and she had so much fun so we kept letting her play it for about a year as i got more and more uncomfortable and stressed out every time she played it then a few months ago she was playing in the kitchen and i was watching it was the roblox version of sims and she started complaining about someone following her the other character was male and had a listed age of her character was clearly a child this guy kept following her around for like minutes and while he couldn't chat to her he was pinging her with requests to go on his shoulders she kept ignoring them then she went to the school and he followed her in then his character took out a fucking assault rifle and started going around shooting people in the head it had no effect because this particular game wasn't set up for that but it was still really upsetting it had very realistic sound effects hubs and i talked that night and we agreed roblox was gone we got her minecraft and while she sometimes complains she's so happy with it also after struggling with the youtube kids account pushing inappropriate content despite the restrictions i learned that with the app you can change it to approved content only which lets you to set it up to only allow videos channels or playlists that you specifically approve it took a bit of work to set up but honestly it's been such a weight off my kid loves it because she doesn't have to constantly check with me about each video she wants to watch

giving him a proper console is light years better than letting him on youtube kids he'll be playing actual full fledged games instead of watching other people play and games with complete stories and experiences instead of free mmos that may be unsuitable for children if he becomes interested in pokemon or mario there's plenty of lore and content linked to that universe itself that'll be exciting for kids and much more appropriate compared to mobile based games in my experience as a private tutor for children youtube is a horrific place if left unsupervised even the kids app there's an insane amount of pornographic themed minecraft story videos and roblox ones for sure one of my first graders was reeled in by it and showed it to me telling me how much he likes the show suffice to say i was mortified and had to spend weeks redirecting him to other content his older brother on the other hand was hooked on pokemon and grew a hobby of reading the comics researching lore drawing watching the shows and even playing older gameboy games on emulators we've had so much engaging discussions and interactions with a hobby in the picture and i find that kids with a focused hobby really thrive in other skills the nintendo switch is also pretty much geared towards children and family friendly games with many multiplayer games to boot you can play with your kid and bond over it many of us grew up with nintendo systems in our childhood and had fond memories of it not all screens are bad it just depends on the content and usage

in my experience with my then year old and year old i say cut it off completely if they are obsessed with it i hate that game their cousins got them into it and then their friends played it we moved recently and then allowed them to play a couple times and it was like night and day i could see their attitude change arguing not wanting to ever get off the game eye rolling due to flashing light games with running around characters games that basically involve gambling we decided roblox and tablets are not for us as a family because of the addictive tendencies it’s like they get sucked into the game …and i get it there’s so many different games on roblox and the multiplayer aspect and chat feature makes it hard to break away but it was so much harder to deal with a time limit rather than just not play at all didn’t matter if they had sports practice and school activities they suddenly hated every activity besides playin roblox good luck i used to search for answers on what to do because that game really messes with my kids temperament

my son has a deep love of minecraft he's always gravitated towards video games though even before that we struggled the first year of his obsessions covid remote kindergarten made it so much worse ughhhh with setting video game limits but his tantrums over quitting and mood in general eventually got bad he was so we had to take a long break like zero zip bass video games he took is surprisingly well we talked a lot about mental health neuro health attention etc he's a very bright kid kids who gravitate towards video games often are very bright and with enough check ins he started seeing how going without video games was helping he said something like yeah i wake up and i don't feel like i have to play anymore after a couple of months we slowly introduced them back setting a strict schedule allowed one hr days of the week and set a timer when timer went off he had min to wrap up and if he threw a fit he would lose his next session my kiddo is now playing hrs on tues and thurs after school and hrs in am and hrs pm on weekend days unless something else is going on this is usually instead of tv movies me and his siblings will watch a movie and he plays video games for instance with this strict schedule and the tough year of work we did he's in a good rhythm no tantrums or yelling at us etc he'll on rare occasion even quit on his own when he gets tired even if he hasn't hit his time quota one thing i've noticed is how video games are sooooo bonding for kids now days other kids his age all play minecraft too so it really helps him relate w others at recess that play make believe minecraft also he plays a mini game where he learns french ha so also i like to remind myself that video games aren't bad and i don't like using language that sounds judgey of the video game playing treating it like junk or whatever i don't want it to be seen as a guilty pleasure that all can actually promote dysfunctional patterns too like sneaking it hiding it playing in middle of the time etc we also make it a habit to have him show us his characters his builds and watch him do some mini games i guess i've kinda come to love minecraft too now that i think about it lol i've never touched the game myself but seeing the creativity and love for it in my son sparks some love of the game ha

we have a or depends ratio for all screen time in our house for every hour off screen time we do or hours of non screen time an hour of roblox means hours or bike riding reading practicing drums helping cook dinner playing a board game etc it has worked really well for our house but that is only because his screen time isn’t “problematic” to me i monitor the content make sure he is only playing with kids we know from school and talk explicitly with him about how to identify dangerous content including content that might be violent racist misogynistic pretending to be science etc i also try to prioritize “useful” screen time; when he builds something cool in minecraft i listen to him walk me thru how he did it if he find a cool trick in some game i ask him to show me how he figured it out lots of his preferred youtube content is science creators or nature creators or people who do woodworking or other hands on stuff a few years ago i sent him to a coding summer camp; this summer he’s going to a “creator camp” that is for engineering stuff that’s kid appropriate it makes me feel like i am doing my best to link all that screen time into some real world stuff to keep it balanced he is now and i feel like it’s been possible to keep the peace in the house going about it this way but i am sure there are tons of good ideas in the thread

it is my absolute pet peeve when parents act like their kids are druggies because they use screens too much he’s and you’re the parent my advice to any parent struggling with screentime add something instead of taking something away and framing it as a punishment is he in sports scouts h robotics or some other fun activity that will get him out of the house and making friends i know it’s winter right now but think about investing in a bike and a bike rack so he can bike different places or a basketball hoop take him to the library every week and look for fun graphic novels or comic books that might hold his attention i also second trying other video games that have more of a plot or provide opportunities to turn it off like playing a match and then you can turn the game off when the match is over

i stopped my son y o from playing roblox after a friend's son had an adult man trying to contact him through the game & after reading articles about the following a dad caught some pervert using the game to virtually molest his kid; he lured the kid into his bedroom in the game & was doing sexual motions another mom said her daughter ended up in sex rooms w the characters having roblox orgies some other guy paid young girls in robux to record themselves & send him the videos once i learned all of this i was like nope there are too many predators on roblox i think video games & electronics in general can become addictive for kids not to mention some of the kids playing online are super toxic & say inappropriate things because they have no adult involvement it's pretty obvious that some of them are just allowed to sit on their games all day & have unrestricted internet access & their parents pay no attention to them which is why i set rules for my kid & enforce them he now mostly plays minecraft & rocket league i do let him play cod sometimes because i'm okay with w military style violence vs gta for example fighting for your country cool hijacking a car not cool but all of his devices are now linked to a parental control service which not only filters content but also alerts me when any content or messages contain certain themes topics or words & i also set time limits once his time is up that's it for the day i don't allow him to play first thing in the morning or before he's done with schoolwork & he isn't allowed to play within an hour of bedtime at random when i feel he needs to detox i have no electronics days where he's not allowed on anything at all & has to read or play outside or play w his non electronic games toys i make sure i balance the electronics w reading & sports & family time before i did all of this he was acting like an addict now he's well balanced & there have even been times when he chose to read instead of playing video games

the people offended that you compared roblox addiction to heroin is something video game addiction in kids is a legitimate concern here's what the mayo clinic website says about it [ consider these tips follow guidelines for screen time such as those suggested by the american academy of pediatrics model healthy use of screens and video games consider unplugging when you first get home from work at dinner and when driving model other methods of relaxation and entertainment such as taking a walk playing a game having a dance party or reading a book encourage a balance between screen time and activities that require in person social interactions such as family activities or extracurricular activities create structured screen free times such as during mealtimes in the mornings and before bedtime consider using apps that control the length of time your child can use a device keep screens out of bedrooms require that all devices be charged outside of bedrooms at night learn about the game rating categories and only allow your children to play video games suitable for their ages

getting rid of roblox i have an yr old son who plays this game and has become obsessed he doesn’t want to stop playing has anyone successfully gotten rid of this game how did you do it how did you explain etc

what's the reason you need to get rid of it entirely roblox is great creative play when done in moderation engage a bit with him have you ever genuinely asked him why he likes playing the game asked him what it takes to be good at the games he plays i know it looks like mush from the outside but there's often more there than you think beyond that you do have to just set limits explain that you want to trust him with his games but he needs to show you that he can put it down let him play tomorrow for literally only minutes you can be right there with him if he's able to put it down nicely after minutes of play he can get minutes tomorrow if not tomorrow is a break day and you can start with only minutes the next day adjust up every few days he's able to be responsible and adjust down whenever he complains and argues at the end of a session these types of compliance systems can essentially auto adjust to what our kids can actually handle eventually you might let it flex up to an hour or so if he's showing appropriate behavior consistently where you can cap it instead of just enforced cold turkey on something your son really enjoys you're teaching him self moderation skills and putting him in the driver's seat of his own game habits

so funny hang in there mama that said don’t feel guilty if you want to say something about it it’s actually not a bad thing to let your kiddos know if you need some quiet time or changes in topic from time to time teaching kids to have empathy for others is a great life skill for not only at home but for social normals with others no one would want to listen about how pink sparkly shoes are the best shoes in the world for hours right sorry it’s a weird random example but hang in there with me or maybe it’s been a long bad day and you’re just not in a mental state where you can hear one more freaking random fact about minecraft without wanting to pull your hair out despite all the love you have for your child and not wanting to crush their soul spirit willingness to share with you in the future but the really important part in teaching these lessons is that you don’t tell them teach this lesson when they are in the middle of sharing otherwise you risk hurting your child and making them feel unconfident in wanting to share with you again in the future do share with them how much you love that they are excited and happy about the topics they bring up that it’s awesome to share with people you love and you know care about you do listen when they share even when it’s not a topic you really care about it’s important to them and it’s the same way you would want to be treated when talking to a friend right do give them time to talk and after actively listening and asking engaging questions go ahead and change subjects to let your child know it’s time for something new to talk about if they don’t get it you can always say “it was really fun to hear about your minecraft story today but i would also love to hear about ” do share and talk about things you like or are excited about with your child too it’s a great way for them to learn about being good listeners and getting an understanding of how healthy conversations work keep in mind of your audience and where they are at developmentally though when bringing up your topics you might have to talk in excited tones and include exclude different facts when talking to a five year old but for a teenager you could have a less animated and more factual discussion do tell your kids when you are having a rough time or are in need of a break and try to tell them in advance so you can avoid hurt feelings example i’ve told my kids “hey i love you guys i just want to give you the head’s up that mom here has had a bit of a rough day i would be super grateful if we could talk and share things later when i know i’m not in a grumpy mood and i can give you the my best listening ears and attention that you deserve “ bottom line it’s nice to have our children share with us but it’s also good to have boundaries and to also acknowledge needs and feelings of everyone

child having meltdowns over tablet minecraft roblox etc okay guys i desperately need advice my son is and became really interested in minecraft and roblox after he downloaded it a few months ago while at his grandmothers house i’ve learned to play both of the apps with him to understand it better & see the positives they’re fun games i admit my issue is every time he has to put the tablet away he has a meltdown every time the duration of these meltdowns vary but it’s stressful for us both tonight i thought about just getting rid of the tablet until weekends to avoid this but i think you all may have more productive advice how should i approach these meltdowns and tablet time things i’ve tried giving him hour per day which he can earn more time or lose time based on behavior and activities this is new but i’m iffy on this method setting a timer so he can see how much he has and giving frequent updates + having a transition activity which he rejects letting him just play all day no limits this did not work at all obviously he is starting school next month which i hope will help naturally but for now he is home all day while i work any advice tips things i’m clearly doing wrong can’t put every detail in this post so ask if you need clarification on anything
i would do a combination of and or go cold turkey yes they're fun but have him try to make some of the things with real blocks legos meltdowns are a sign of screen addiction

say you only want him to use it for minutes figure out how much battery you need to charge it up to so that it will die after that much time then when he is allowed to play you just say okay you can play until it dies feels more open ended to him but kinda isn’t

my daughter's tablet has a screen time limiter so after a certain amount of time that i select the tablet will just no longer allow access would it be possible to set your own timer and give the opportunity for him to give it up on his own but then set up a parental lock one as a backup so he doesn't even have the option to continue to play i think if he has a meltdown you just need to calmly explain you understand he's upset because playing the game is very fun but we need to take breaks and give our eyes and brains some time to rest if he continues to meltdown just be available but don't respond to the tantrum give hugs when he's starting to calm down even if he's still crying but when it's passed the height of the meltdown

one hour is too long the big problem i see with my own five year old is that he asks for video games when he's feeling too tired or uncomfortable to entertain himself playing a game and having to stop just delays satisfying the need he needs to satisfy so he melts down at the end so my rule is that before playing he has to have had a drink eaten something of substance within the last hour and gone to the toilet if there has been evidence of overstimulation or poor regulation during the day so far he can't play not as a punishment but because he'll probably have more difficultly holding himself together and then i set an alarm for twenty minutes if it's a solo game like teach your monster to read or half an hour for a game he needs help for like spiro the dragon he can finish the level life savepoint stage after the timer goes off but not start a new one after that check in with bodily needs again and maybe ease back to reality with a cuddle and a story

when my child has a fit about it being time to turn off the electronics he isn’t allowed to play with it the next day like my son had a fit tantrum last week about having to stop playing a game on the nintendo switch switch and i told him “it’s not good for your brain for a video game to be this important to you no switch tomorrow ” and then don’t cave no matter what that is the most important part every time he has the fit he loses it for a day potentially longer if a day turns out to not be long enough my son is a bit older so the “not good for your brain” has been explained more and now i can say that being addicted to video games isn’t good for his brain and feeling this upset about turning them off is a sign that he’s getting addicted so time for a game break but at he wouldn’t have known what addicted meant this has really helped in our house he understands the “why” and it definitely curbs the behavior because he doesn’t want to lose the device
for me it was easier to have fewer longer sessions do you work with him to find a good ending point open ended games can be hard to stop
if my son freaks out when i tell him it's time to get off electronics he loses them for hours the threat of not being able to play the next day almost always works
with and added rule have a meltdown when tablet time is over that means no tablet time tomorrow
ime an hour is too long for many yos i would start with minutes my kid plays mostly switch games and we have a timer on the switch when it goes off it’s done
he's throw the tablet out the window

reacting to the meltdown may be rewarding the behavior young children don't know how to regulate their feelings and equate any reaction or attention as just that attention whether it's positive or negative child melts down you say that you understand he is frustrated remind him of the minute and minute warnings let him know that meltdowns mean less screen time tomorrow when he's calm talk to him about what might be a good activity for him to do after screen time that way when you give the minute warning you can remind him what comes next maybe drawing what he made online or a completely unrelated activity

try to pre empt it if you know he's about to melt down but be calmed by cuddles offer the cuddle before he starts that way he learns that he can get the cuddle *without* throwing a wobbly and you get to respond to his needs without having to overanalyze too much

this is more true when the consequence doesn’t fit with the problem behavior for example not letting a kid have dessert because they were mean to a sibling earlier that day delayed when it is a natural consequence that was immediately explained is psychologically different i’m not denying that he’ll probably have another meltdown tomorrow about not getting the tablet but that doesn’t mean they should just let him have it especially with screen addiction being a concern a tweak that could be made to have it be even more of a natural consequence is to have a system where when he stops playing it he plugs it in to charge for the next day if he has a fit and mom or dad has to take it then “oh hey you had a fit instead of plugging it into the charger so now it’s dead ”

i'd say it's a little different if it's a kid from their class at school or some group they're in like dance or girl scouts i'm referring to getting phone numbers from random people online they got through a videogame like roblox my daughter was probably or a little older but they kept telling us they \*had\* to play roblox with their friends at exactly pm every day or they would throw a fit i knew they played with their friends who live down the street so i didn't mind so much then she started acting really suspicious about hiding the screen anytime i walked by so after she was done with her minute session i opened it back up and looked at the group chat log yep not her friends down the street but a bunch of internet drama with like random people about how her boyfriend was teaming up with some other girls instead of her because we made her quit after minutes not only that but my kid had proactively told this boy what city she lived in what her parents did how old she was etc he supposedly lived in pennsylvania and she wanted him to come visit holy crap this violates like every online safety rule that both her school and our family have reviewed repeatedly the ipad went away for a while roblox was deleted i debated logging on and having a little dad chat with this kid but decided against it that's when we finally decided to get serious about locking down the ipad with parental controls

> > if this is like the dog walkers i see walking like dogs at once in a maze of leashes that walker is making bank they might be the problem with dog walking as a business is the logistics if you can find dogs in the same suburb to walk all of them at the same time you can make bank for sure but remember that walk has to last an hour form pickup to drop off and you need to pick up and drop off all those dogs so the reality is that dogs going for walk is just about a full day's work when you account for all the time overhead and that assumes that you can find customers that all live close enough together that you can do the walk as group for walks means a walk dogs a day means a day now that's assuming that you actually have enough customers to do days work a week that above example is only walks a week so if we assume you're only working days a week it's a week from there you'd need to pay taxes like a small business before you'd pay yourself there's not a lot of expenses in dog walking so you don't get a ton of deductions most dog walking businesses acquire customers just through social media it's often a who you know kind of operation so there might be some facebook ads that you'd need to run and staying on top of all the customer communications will be a pain in the ass even if you have a stable group of customers there's bound to be some churn so you always need to be hustling for that next customer having said all that k a week for a job that you really only need to work days a week is decently good there's just not a lot of room to grow that business above a person operation

i’ve asked this myself too our son is but in rd grade as one of if not the youngest kid in the class he made the cut off by a week but is pretty smart so pre school told us to get him in and not hold him back almost all of his friends are and i definitely can see they act more mature than he does our son also has a degree of sensory processing disorder and gets very emotional very quickly sometimes without reason so it’s a balance of trying to protect him from social anguish from friends and being the one to cause him the emotional distress for the most part we don’t dissuade him unless it’s a pretty drastic situation most kids are self aware enough to know something they enjoy may be perceived in a less than desirable way and often don’t care or aren’t aware yet because they’ve never been made fun of which quite honestly is part of growing up and learning social norms i think it’s more important for them to find out from peers than their parents who are supposed to be their base of support back your daughter up if she changes her mind go with the flow for reference all of my sons friends were doing birthday parties at bounce houses laser tag go karts and arcades he wanted to do his at a paint your own pottery place because it’s quiet and relaxing to him he gets very overwhelmed and shuts down quickly at loud birthday parties so we let him do what would make him happy even if the other boys may not be keen on it then again half his invitee list were girls who were thrilled with the party so there’s that

your daughter turning and wanting a bluey themed birthday party is absolutely delightful it's important to remember that children develop at their own pace and interests can vary widely your daughter's love for baby dolls and playing house is perfectly normal for her age and it's wonderful that she enjoys these activities planning a bluey themed party sounds like a fantastic idea especially since you both share an enthusiasm for it while kids at school may sometimes act older it's essential to celebrate your daughter's unique interests when inviting girls from school consider mentioning the bluey theme and gauge their reactions some may still find joy in such playful themes and your daughter might discover shared interests it's a great opportunity to celebrate her individuality while fostering connections with peers who appreciate similar activities encourage her to be herself and she might find kindred spirits who enjoy playing like little girls too other themes could be added to provide a contrast for kids who might not find the bluey theme as engaging activities like games ping pong water balloon fights etc even using roblox i hope this was helpful and i wish you and your child all the best

i definitely hovered over her more i didn't allow her to do some things at ages that i have since let her little or brother do who is years younger than her i was very naive as a child and a teenager and i didn't want her to be the same i tried to prepare her for all the horrible people in the world and in doing so i projected my own insecurities and fears onto her luckily she is so emotionally mature and exceptionally intelligent that she does not have the same fears and insecurities however i realize i shouldn't have been trying to shield her as much because i could have very well given her the same fears and insecurities that i do have when she was she moved to montana to live with her dad because she had spent her first years of life with me and she missed her dad and her sisters over there and the biggest reason was that their high school only had about students whereas our high school here has over students so i agreed to let her move and since she's moved i've learned a lot of things i kind of put her in that older sister guaranteed babysitter role that she didn't need to be in i expected her to behave about years older than she always was because she was so intelligent and she was so mature i often forgot what a typical child her age would look like or how they would act because she never acted her actual age she always acted older so when we were at the mall or something for example if she had some behavior that was not typical for her but baby typical for an year old when she was she would get in trouble because we felt that she should be acting more like a year old so she ended up kind of getting small punishments because she wasn't acting her age in our eyes because we saw her as a year old but she really was acting her age and her own eyes because she really was an year old does that make sense it's really hard to put it all into writing because a lot of it seems very very small when you just write it out and list it i don't think that really shows the seriousness and the gravity of what i did to harm our relationship she was never abused physically or emotionally but she did feel like her stepdad and i expected way too much of her so she always felt like she would never be able to live up to her expectations she craved positive attention and we gave her plenty we thought but she has told me that she never felt like we were truly proud of her because we didn't act with as much excitement after her plays or when she aced a test or something like that a lot of the struggle for most of her childhood we thought related to the fact that she was years older than her little brother so even though we were treating them the same as each other as far as how we punished them or what kinds of things they were allowed to have it was at different times for example when my daughter was five that's when she started doing chores she started with simple things like putting her own clothes away taking out the bathroom garbage and maybe wiping down the bathroom sink by the time her brother was five she was so she had more age appropriate chores and her little brother had the same chores she had when she was five well in her nine year old brain she thought it was unfair because she had more to do than her brother i tried to explain to her that when she was five she had the same amount of chores but it was difficult for her to understand because she didn't remember well she has kind of felt like her little brother got better treatment his whole life because of things like that where i did treat him exactly the same as i traded her when she was his age she feels like we often favored him things like when her brother played baseball we would all attend games and we would cheer and tell him how great he did and all that stuff after the game but she never played a sport she was always in drama and i absolutely loved it she is so insanely talented and she has a real passion for acting and directing and writing but you don't really cheer during a play you don't shout over the crowd yeah good job way to remember your lines nice job talking loud enough for everyone to hear you but we said all of those things and more when it was over we gushed at how great she played her role but to her it didn't feel the same i can kind of understand that as i was in marching and concert band growing up and my brothers played sports my parents hated instrumental music and they absolutely loved sports but i recognize the fact that my parents were every one of my band concerts they always made sure i had my instrument and the things i needed to be able to play it they always came to parades or band competitions to watch me even though it was so dull and boring for them and they always told me how great i did and how proud they were of me and i could tell it was forced but it didn't negate the fact that they really were proud of me they just didn't know how to show it because they had only ever attended sporting events i guess she always felt that we weren't as proud of her as we were of her brother playing baseball which is completely untrue but i guess we didn't show it in a way that she could see it there are some things that she has told me that i don't understand or i don't agree with her viewpoint of how we acted or reacted or treated her in general but i recognize and understand that her feelings are hers alone and they're not for me to understand they're only for me to accept and i can try to ask for clarification and i can try to get some sort of understanding as to what i did wrong or where i went wrong and i might never get that all i know is that my daughter and i are not as close as we used to be and it hurts and if i could go back and do it again i would remind myself every single day not to make the same mistakes

to compare my life to someone else 🙄 and she's one of those who thinks that because she did something she hated doing as a parent then we my brothers and i should too for example christmas time my whole life i thought it was completely normal to have to go to different houses for christmas one side of my family rotated each year so occasionally christmas would be at our house but usually we weren't home for christmas at all we woke up opened gifts and ate breakfast and then left we didn't get to use play with our presents until we were home later that night when my husband and i got married he spent the first year doing christmas with me as my family normally did it as all of his family lives mi away after that he was like nope i'm not doing that every year our kids should get to play with the stuff we get for them that's the best part of christmas i never realized it was weird so when i explained to my mom that we'd be missing over half of the christmases and told her that if she wanted to see the kids open their gifts from us she'd have to come over to our house she threw a fit saying things like well i did it and made it work and you guys never complained when you were empath and people's emotions affect me at times but she's strong and supportive she's apologized for things she said and did when she was raising us and she said she also doesn't remember saying those things i think it's because parenting was a different mindset back then it was more about obeying and the parent is never wrong and such whereas i feel like today parents are much more aware of the words they say having an impact on their kids because we've all been to therapy now 😂
