need some non judgmental advice my y o spends way too much time on roblox my y o who will be in december spends hours and hours of her free time either playing roblox or watching youtube videos of these people playing roblox she loves creating art she’s a great reader she’s into food and baking enjoys basketball likes activity i hate seeing her spend so much time on this video game or on youtube i also have a and an almost y o i’m also the sahd and do of household tasks etc i have had days when we’ve done better with other activities and days when she just doesn’t want to quit roblox i hate how addictive this video game is any advice to get her off of this

just say no i know how unhelpful that sounds but there really is no way around it at this age you opened pandora's box by allowing her to start the game in the first place you need very clear expectations and rules for how long and when she gets to play use timers enforce it maybe she earns the game for a positive action whatever works for you make sure you explain *why* videogames are limited brain junk food no time for school sleep no family connection etc her brain is addicted to the stimulus and it is a novelty it might take time to wean her off so you could start reducing her play time gradually if you try and cut her off cold turkey it will likely just lead to power struggles and anger she likes this and you allowed it so now arbitrarily taking it away is going to feel very unfair and confusing the ultimate goal is to achieve a predictable mutually agreed outcome in which she can have her game and once she sort of gets used to *not* having it constantly and starts finding other ways to fill her time she might not ask for it as much fyi you should monitor her activity closely in the game my kids aren't into this one personally but i have heard it is possible for creeps to interact with kids if they have public access i don't know how it works because as i said this isn't a favorite in our house but you should look into it

figure out times that you’re okay with her having access to roblox while you cook dinner on weekends so you have time to destress a bit and then tell her those times are times she can play roblox also find new ways to nurture her passions she loves doing art take her to below and have her pick out some new art supplies to try out maybe y’all can try a new recipe together or even do some menu planning year olds can do a lot in the kitchen if she’s reading independently build regular library trips into your schedule if she’s not already sign her up for basketball at the ymca you need to make non roblox activities more appealing

mine was the same with minecraft though we had a new baby and it kept him occupied during the time he enjoyed it but he began to spend all of his time doing exactly what your daughter is doing and his behavior was suffering too just epic meltdowns super moody and not himself because of meltdowns tantrums we took away the playstation and tablet for two weeks at a time first few days were brutal but he started going back to the things he used to love drawing independent play going outside etc he obviously needed more direction and help finding the next task to do to keep him occupied but i don’t regret it then when he would get his tablet and stuff back he would play for awhile and then randomly get bored and do something else much like adults when you decide your indulging too much into something and you try and fill your time with other things that one big thing starts to lose its hold over you you could start with limiting screen time maybe just completely cut out the youtube too that place is garbage and unless you are closely monitoring they’ll be exposed to all sorts of weird shit like peppa pig with blood oozing out of her mouth

so for limiting screen time at my house we don’t use specific amounts of time as that’s not super intuitive but rather times of day on school days my kids are not allowed screen time in the morning or after school they need to get ready in the am and do homework or help out after school then they can play but after supper they can have screen time until an hour before bedtime then it’s time to get ready for bed and read for half hour or so this gets them about an hour mins a day for screens on weekdays depending on when we have supper weekends they have screen time before i get up in the morning then not again until after supper so probably hours on the weekend i find because it’s our routine they don’t really fight me on it as they know when there will be time for screens i do make some exceptions for my teenager as he wants to use more of his free time to play online chess and logic games i also make exceptions if someone is sick the weather is bad or we are all feeling seriously burned out but most of the time that is our routine and it works well

you are the parent so you decide how long she uses it for will she like limits no does she like being told what to do or told off no it'll be hard at first to wean her off it but do it there will be lots of i'm bored and maybe tantrums but you set limits my daughter is and only gets minutes on her tablet she would also play for hours then be so overly stimulated that she can't calm down so she knows it's limited she also knows she has to do her chores or tasks in order to get tablet time so it's a reward for behaving
have activities available but allow her to be bored as long as she isn't being destructive it is totally okay to let her just be
limit screen time to hours i typically let my son watch tv or play a game after school until i start cooking around

she's so capable of understanding basic rules sit her down and talk to her about the new rules around roblox and why you're doing this tell her set times ie when you cook dinner when you are cleaning xyz kids that age don't really understand the concept of actual time so associate screen time to events like cooking or folding laundry once you establish this stick to it it'll suck for a while because once it sinks in she won't like it but tell her she's free to do any other activity other than things associated to a screen

gamer dad here there are two different elements to your situation that need to be considered one is screen time and addiction games just like tv and books are designed to get your attention with an interesting story and like puzzles jigsaws and board games they're designed to make you want to keep trying to win the challenge on top of that they have replayability and are never exactly the same each time you play it young kids cannot be expected to self regulate against this you must set boundaries no matter how much they beg and whine explain to your kids why the boundaries are important to you but don't give in the other element is the online social network built into some games just like facebook your kids are messaging and talking with other people through the game do you know exactly who they are talking to just because the other person's profile says they are doesn't mean it's true i do let my kids play minecraft but only on my own server that can only be accessed inside my house so they get to do all kinds of fun things within our family world building sharing and problem solving and yes after an hour they are very unhappy to be torn away but i know what it's like and i know the feeling passes to be honest i'd still prefer they spent their screen time playing games instead of watching the nth repeat of some animated cartoon i haven't used roblox but it does look like they have some offline features you could look into that

as a teenager who used to play roblox for hours on end at the same age as your daughter i'd say to try to slowly pull her away from it my parents weren't that involved with what i did in my free time essentially screen time so i spent most of my time playing video games i definitely would have preferred it if they tried to manage my time after looking backon it but i grew out of it on own and i'm now a perfectly fine student in highschool if you're not already familiar adopt me is a game where kids can pretend to have families something of the sort in terms of appearance it's harmless a lot of kids play this game and i'm pretty sure it's the most popular game on the site this may give you some false pretenses but if you think about it a lot of games out there have many inappropriate ideas in the real world i e shooting people and it's essentially the same here i personally think it would be extremely uncomfortable for her if you were overly assertive like others are recommending to be with stopping her i think it's better to expose to her more healthy hobbies we all have weird things we liked to participate in but it's something that most of us tend to grow out of admittedly if my parents found out about all the stuff i've seen played they'd think i'm crazy but look at me now i'm a healthy student with great grades and i look back on my past and laugh a bit monitor her but most importantly don’t turn a blind eye edit last sentence was a little sketch lol

my two kids also play roblox but i have some ground rules in place otherwise they will play all day if i let them over the summer my rule was no playing till after lunch and no playing after dinner understand that they will yell scream ask say i'm bored etc and it's okay eventually the boredom will lead them to find something else to do and hopefully enjoy it also have to lead by example by being off electronic devices myself there are good days and bad days this morning my daughter was sulking for almost an hour because i wouldn't let her play before school started to take it out of your hands and to provide consistency and expectations for your daughter i second putting parental controls on the computer to only allow access at certain times unfortunately my circumstances won't allow that right now but i find that if my kids understand that if the answer is already no they react a whole lot better than if they expect to play and the answer is no which was why this morning was worse for my daughter

i think the fact that you are asking the question is enough… especially because your kid has been saying it already maybe it’s time to go to her and say “hey i’m sorry i’ve been so strict i’m worried about you and i let that get the best of me forgive me and let’s collaborate on a reasonable plan moving forward i don’t want to alienate you and i also want you to not be harmed but i know you’ll be hurt in this messed up world and i don’t need to make you suffer because of that ” and then hug yayyy my kiddo had me watch some scott pilgrim movie today and i was completely and utterly shocked that the film had a yr old man dating a year old “schoolgirl” and everyone seemed to be okay with it … but we just talked about it and i might’ve went overboard every single time it came back up on the screen saying how terrible and unbelievable i think it is my strategy is borrowed from my father who would just let me engage any material and would actually engage it with me i have many stories where we watched or listened to something and he intervened on a thought i had and it was a very helpful intervention that no one my age would make i say that to say there might be some balance you can strike maybe you can ask her what she thinks and come to some compromise understanding i want my son to have some agency in his life and at the same time i understand and communicate to him that there are limits because for example porn is really not meant for kids do i tell him not to watch porn yes do i tell him why i think he shouldn’t yes do i expect that he won’t ever watch porn noooo of course he’ll be exposed to it even the cartoons have erotic things going on but when he sees the material he is reminded of the ways that we engaged it — he knows how i feel and hopefully he thinks i have some worthy perspective to consider and then he’ll navigate how he feels he should it’s hard to let go but it might actually bring you closer also look how helpful technology is for you we were watching videos to teach him how to do animation on youtube the other day and he learns about different aspects of music theory he’s and often teaches me what he learns it comes with crap like scott my son has adhd and he has had a phone since he was in kindergarten our routine was it would go in the backpack when he got home it would go straight to a bowl if he wanted to use it for games he would ask and we would let him have it for min during the week as long as homework and chores were done i also installed google family link both my husband and i are supervisors and can lock his phone from anywhere or block apps however he didn't start to use it for friends until the last months my kids are not allowed to play roblox but they do play minecraft my husband will also play with them at times he also started playing that with friends he prefers to use kid messenger to chat with his friends too youtube we have it restricted to older kid on google family link i do check to see what he's watching sometimes to make sure he's not watching anything he shouldn't now that he likes his phone even more we switched our house to earning phone time he recently got braces so good teeth brushing earns phone time chores and homework earn phone time behavior and doing his best in school just like any kids we have not approved apps or purchases taken the phone away for not listening etc at times i've had to lock his phone so i could get his attention once he's done what i needed i unlock it and he can go back to what he was doing we also have set times for when the phone will lock for the night and unlock the next day it's always the same time every day so there aren't surprises one of our biggest rules is if they complain over this then they won't get their phone the next day i try to give them a min warning before the phone will lock for the night and that seems to help overall we can control content and usage he knows and it's not an issue since it's been like that from the beginning

my f experience going through middle and high school which was only a few years ago sounds a decent amount like your daughter’s my family didn’t have internet access at home no one had a laptop until i went to university i got a phone after i graduated from high school and had an ipod touch before that but without internet communication with that is useless i worked too hard in school and got some of the highest grades in my class but i had no friends and even through university and into my post school life i struggle immensely to relate to people my age because i don’t have the same context for conversations and the interests they have based around the internet like gaming or social media feel kind of frivolous to me i know they aren’t i respect people enjoying whatever they enjoy as long as it doesn’t hurt anyone but i can’t talk for minutes let alone hours about video games i don’t resent or regret how my parents raised me but i do feel like the choice they made for me will effect me for many more years than just the time i didn’t have a phone op i would suggest considering where your kid is at in respect to how well you think they can make friends in general how well they may be able to handle any of the many challenges that come with technology and what supports or bridges you can make for them

is banning all video games really the only way to go does anyone else have a problem with their kids playing video games they seem way more addictive than when i was a kid i've let my kids play for a few years now they played my old ds and my old xbox they never seemed obsessed and did other things now they have phones when they get game time all they play is roblox when game time is finished all they talk about is roblox when they turn on the tv they find streamers playing roblox they are half assing their studies in order to get to game time faster when we take it away for any length of time it is incessant questioning of when they'll get it back or constant bargaining 'if i do x can i get it back ' it's got to the point where my wife wants to just ban video gaming altogether i'm inclined to agree i never wanted to be 'that' dad but man this behaviour is just crazy to me and i think maybe it'll be for the best

i was “addicted” to computers and video games as a kid my parents never once gave me grief about it all i would do was talk about video games with my friends would avoid other activities to play my schoolwork never really suffered i began making maps and tinkering with modding games with friends i made fan websites about games eventually went to college for game design and now a successful software engineer sometimes passions and addictions turn into lucrative careers perhaps try to get them to also do some learning and productive things with their gaming love

my nephew does nothing but play roblox my wife and i moderate screen time extensively and only allow the baby to watch cartoons in the car for no more than an hour we travel often and tv is highly regulated as well instead we engage the kids in other ways my opinion video games are okay and my wife and i both are pretty avid gamers moderation as in all things is key we encourage our kids to play other video games than the normal ones such as roblox or minecraft and we play dnd sometimes with our oldest i personally believe those geared specifically to children are predatory having gamed for almost years i've never seen anything quite like them i may be having a boomer moment though

video games saved my life from a neglectful childhood

board games playing outside walks chalk drawings sitting and reading with them they help cook dinner sensory bins are awesome other screen based media that isn't geared towards children like nature documentaries going to spend the evening with family or friends especially friends with children regardless of age the baby loves my new truck and we just roll around and listen to different music she loves deathcore or audiobooks going to new places and explaining how people do their jobs just engage them in any way possible and when you get sick of it tv time my kids are absolute fucking sponges and soak everything up because that's how we raised them the oldest has a full ride to a very prestigious university teach them everything they'll love it as long as you know how to discipline the individual child not as a rule of thumb the oldest i use my disappointment the youngest time out and maybe a swat on the butt once every couple months when she's just horrible the way i view it is that i separate my professional and personal lives i further compartmentalize my relationships between all of my girls i also never let my anger influence my dealings with them including my wife i have an obligation to put something better into the world and i'm doing a damn fine job have fun figuring it out because like my oldest it's over far too soon

present problem my step son will be seven in about a week and a half he shows no interest in anything other than his tablet roblox minecraft and youtube he has minecraft toys and roblox toys that he won’t play with when he wakes up he gets on his tablet before he goes to school when he comes home he gets on his tablet til it’s time to sleep he has a problem and refuses to put it down wife doesnt’ think it’s a problem what are some present idea’s for a child that only wants to play his tablet

take it away or set up a schedule and make sure you follow through with it for example hour of tablet time after school engage with him in other ways when he doesn’t have it like get him a bike or a trampoline or take him to the park it won’t be easy at first but he’ll be better off

you have to remove the screens period this will be difficult of course but once you’ve warned he will figure out other things to do he likes roblox try legos or magnet tiles so he can build things my son enjoys video games but he also loves playing pretend with his action figures he is also again i know it will be really tough at first but the screens have to go once you’ve gone a few weeks or months without them you can hopefully reintroduce them with limitations for example we don’t allow any screens before school and no video games during the week if my kids are well behaved and have taken care of all their responsibilities for the day they can usually watch an hour of tv in the evening we aren’t as strict on the weekends but usually are out and about so it’s not a big concern does he do any sort of activities soccer play dates with other kids bike riding just being busy and being outside prevents screen usage in the end though if his mother doesn’t see this behavior as an issue and it really sounds like it is then nothing is going to happen his mom needs to he on board here

screen time i have a year old kid and lately she has been playing too many games like roblox which she says many of her friends are playing i limited her screen time to hours but she's arguing that she needs more am i being too harsh
if she thinks she “needs” and not wants more she’s probably got an addiction i would cut it down even further to an hour
hours is plenty as long as she has a minute warning to finish up tasks my kid plays for hours as well though i usually end up giving him an additional few minutes to say bye to friends

something i'm finding works well for encouraging balance is the one hour rule so in my house our rule is that you can spend a maximum of one hour at a time just sitting on a device after an hour you have to get up and do something else preferably something either productive or active for at least an hour before screen time is on the table again screen time is a privilege not a right of course and if you complain about the rules or use it inappropriately it can be taken away i want my kids to take away the lesson that screens should be just one of several possible options a maximum of of their free time after you take into account sleeping time chores time meal time ect works out to a very small portion of his day maybe of his day max and some days none at all because we're busy i feel that's a very reasonable amount of time to spend on screens

i would start by not telling her about when your getting paid she doesn’t need to know it sucks but sometimes in situations like these you just have to say no and mean it it’s hard when they get mad and throw fits but you need to nip this in the bud now before she is acting this way when shes it’ll be a lot worse then you could also try having her do easy chores and give her like five bucks a week or even two weeks and she’ll have to make it last for her games or whatever then she can start learning early about money and managing it

>she complains constantly her brothers birthday in thursday she's going to cry and whine that she's not getting anything and he gets more stuff than her what you haven't said is how you respond to complaining and whining and presumably having tantrums constantly your response to this is going to be important in well mine anyway a response draw your line make your expectations clean set boundaries then stick to them never ever cave or compromise one thing and that's it then do the one thing and nothing else don't negotiate with terrorists is my favourite term when talking about dealing with children im sorry that your early life kinda sucked; and from experience i know how that parlays into overcompensation and spoiling of one's kids but you're not doing _yourself_ or her to be honest an favours by not setting reasonable expectations and enforcing limits next time before you get her anything sit her down hey its tuesday that means we go to the store when we get there i will get you _one_ <thing she wants> but that's it until next tuesday and i mean it no tantrums no complaining and then do not under any circumstances go back on that until next tuesday if you do this two or three cycles in a row and hold to your restriction and promise then im willing to bet it goes away but during those first few cycles you're in for a rough time whining complaints im sorry i said one you got one that's it until tuesday be prepared for how you handle a tantrum my advice ignore her completely if she wants to flop on the floor and throw stuff and act like err a yr old having a tantrum ignore her i mean like make sure she doesn't hurt herself but otherwise whe she gets in your face and screams in your ear calmly turn to her and say im sorry you feel that way but you're not behaving very nicely come back to me when you're willing to behave nicely and not scream in my ear gonna be tough but it will bear fruit this will sound rather cold but i think its appropriate as a parent your job isn't to be your child's best friend if your child winds up being your best friend that's a bonus and of course im not saying not to love your child to the moon and back and show it every minute of every day but your job isn't to cater and pamper their every need and whim your job is to get them to adulthood and lead by example and part of that is learning there are rules and limits and expectations and boundaries giving them everything they want when they want isn't going to teach them to be anything but needy helpless codependent whiners edit another thing as i come back to this a few hours later you're the parent don't feel the need to ever explain or justify any rule or decision to your kids just keep it simple sorry we can't afford it what are they gonna do audit the books or no i said no that's all you need to know is no or and this actually worked with my kids yep i said so completely arbitrary reason guess what im the adult i get to make up arbitrary rules im the parent deal with it when you're the adult you get to make arbitrary rules for you kids circle of life go ask grandma and grandpa they'll tell ya the same thing they made arbitrary rules that i thought sucked when i was your age so im just passing the buck onto you < i like this one because it shows you acknowledge the unfairness i e acknowledge their pain shows _empathy_ you just don't care

stop buying stuff just stop period sit her down and tell her that you want to teach her and her brother lessons about being thankful for the things she has and that you won't be buying anything new for her or her brother unless it's necessary school stuff for example or a special occasion birthdays easter whatever when she whines and cries and throws a fit remind her this is one of those lessons instead of buying something new let's talk about the cool things we already have you'll like get something about how nothing she owns is cool and then it's time to bring out the big black bags ok when we get home we'll put all the stuff you think isn't cool in big black garbage bags and get it out of your room we're still not buying anything new though i'd also remind them of expectations and put consequences to the actions let them know before you go into the store each time we're not buying toys today we're only buying groceries or before playing roblox you can play but if you ask me about payday or buying things the game is going away then follow through you have to follow through on everything or the boundary is a fantasy and kids know that as a sidenote if this is still an issue months from now i signed the family up to volunteer for toys for toys one year when my kiddo was being particularly greedy he had to help give away so many toys and he saw how happy it made people he was yo and it helped some but there was still work to be done lol

maybe your daughter and yourself might benefit from spending good quality time together it sounds like your daughter is trying to get something from you she's asking for material things because you probably have given her a lot of things seeing that you feel bad you've always had trouble bonding with her so that's what she knows to ask but it might be positive to shift the perspective and give more importance to time spent together etc maybe also to tell her why you appreciate and love her as a person why she is valuable and slowly start shifting the narrative you have that you can only provide things and that she needs those things my interpretation might be a stretch and of you don't recognize yourself in it please ignore my comment you don't really say enough to make such assumptions but something told me it might be part of what's going on and with many people commenting saying you need to tell her no and she must learn i think it's also important that you learn how to give differently i don't think a child that age is responsible for behaving that way and i think there's no need to blame anyone but rather to change what can be changed hopefully for the best good luck

time to introduce the word no into your vocabulary this is different than your normal no it is still no in minutes minutes minutes hours and days later start now by sitting them both down and letting them know there is a new mom in town and this non stop begging whining will not be tolerated anymore i guarantee she does not do it at school she does it with you because she can if she starts she gets warned and if she continues she gets sent to her room or removed etc the key will be to explain before hand and then stick to it

instead of buying everything for my son i ask him if he wants to put it on his birthday list of the time it's a yes the other he's like naw i don't want it that bad this is a tip i read on reddit when he was a baby and it has worked out really well he's now he gets the acknowledgement that i heard him and we can write it down then about a month before his birthday we go over the list to see if he still wants it side note sometimes i don't write it down and we forget it was ever said don't tell him

i totally agree with the others about not giving in to the tantrums however one 'positive parenting' technique that always helped a bit with my son was sort of acknowledging the wishes for things he wanted to do or buy and even expanding on them into silly fantasy 'yeah that would be awesome huh it'd be fun to stay at the playground and slide all night long even until tomorrow or maybe live at the the playground where would you sleep ' and taking pictures of items he liked in stores 'we aren't buying anything today but do you want me to take a picture of it that would be cool to have huh it'd be fun if we bought every single toy in the store but then we wouldn't have room to walk in our house ' but if he was deciding to be stubborn and tantrum about it then it was just go sit outside the store for a few minutes until he calmed down also your daughter doesn't need to know about your money situation it'll sound like too much money if you have a lot and it'll stress her out too much if you don't have enough and you don't need to justify your decisions to her based on finances you're the mom and you just get to decide what you want to do

no complaining allowed shut it down at the first complaint this means consistency stop whatever is happening and make it abundantly clear tantrums need to be addressed immediately and it could mean abruptly going to the car until she’s ready to stop causing a scene teaching breathing exercises to help her control her emotions is helpful expressing emotions is ok but she needs to know there is a time place and appropriate way to do so it sounds like a lot for her age but children are smart resilient and react well to firm consistent behavior by adults i’ve raised three and these tactics worked even for stubborn kids she needs to know that she doesn’t get gifts when it isn’t her birthday or celebration it’s important she understands it now the more you reiterate it without feeding into the drama she will learn consistency consistency consistency even when it’s inconvenient or you don’t feel like it if you don’t she will learn that she can wear you down good luck

you child is saying “jump” and you’re doing it i think you’re going to have to put up with some tantrums now in order to gain back your parental authority sit a the table and tell her that the money you make must take care of your families’ needs first tell her to play with what she has and to quit comparing her possessions to others get a big calendar and put a chore or two a day every day on it tell her she gets a star for each chore she does without being told when she get x number of stars then you will give her a reward it doesn’t have to be expensive if she blows up ask her to leave the area until she can be pleasant then stick to it
yea you need to grow a back bone mama tell her no and don’t cave she doesn’t need any explanation “we are not buying anything at the store today ” let her throw a fit she needs to learn

my kids have “chore money” that they get every week once they complete their jobs and honestly that helped so much if they wanted something in the store i’d just ask them if they had enough for it if they didn’t they had to save up for it and for big things i’d say “ooh put that on your birthday christmas list ” it’s okay to say no to kids the things that they think they “need” are usually just wants of course in some cases like if we were grocery shopping i’d let them choose one kind of fruit they liked or their favorite yogurt or something but they learned to not expect me to buy them whatever they wanted

i'd start taking away the device when you're out running errands less time on the tablet less distraction to mindlessly spend plus keeping her constantly glued to a screen to keep her entertained is not a good habit when she's in school she's not going to be given a decide during boring activities she'll be expected to pay attention explain to her that you'll no longer be buying any goodies outside of holidays or special occasions if she knows going into the store that there's no possibility or a treat she'll not pester you as much make sure you stick to the plan though if you give in she'll just fuss more the next time you say no

before her brother’s birthday sit down and have a chat explain to her that she has to be a good sport it’s his birthday so she can be happy for him and ask him nicely if she can play with him or she can sit in her room whining isn’t an option i think you need to have a chat with her and her brother and explain some new rules my mom had a rule when i was growing up called “i will not complain ” essentially it was a nicer way to say “you get what you get and you don’t throw a fit ” you need to be grateful for the things you are getting because not everyone gets those opportunities if you act like a spoiled brat you lose your privileges to “extra” things like playing roblox i’m not sure what your life looks like outside of this but you might want to start making an effort to replace money with quality time family walks little hikes a trip to the zoo or aquarium a “girls day” to get hot chocolate and then drive around and look at ducks on the lake etc are all fun and free inexpensive spending more time together helps build relationships it’s super easy to just throw money at people and “buy” relationships but an unplugged walk makes you all talk a little bit and learn about each other i say this only because i suffer from depression as well but walks in nature help so much exercise releases endorphins and nature does as well

why not have her work small chores throughout the week with calendar and stickers for a tiny surprise on friday evenings the surprise could be as simple as a movie with chips i would go with the you are old enough to work for your stuff now surprise can be anything a treat a toy something unexpensive edit also she has an ipad i would limit the screen time if you don't already it's proven to make kids nasty also also you don't have to 'explain' to her that she doesn't need to know when your pay is it's none of her buisiness period just don't tell her you got this mama

i think you’ve gotten a ton of great advice with either sticking to no or giving an allowance something to add though i’d start being unfair it sounds mean i know i’ve done this with my kids and now as teens older children it’s served them well what i mean by this is basically if i’m out shopping without kids and see something i like for kid i buy it for just the one kid and give it to them in front of the others next time i grab something for someone else and repeat over time my mantra is “life isn’t fair and i wouldn’t be doing you any favours raising you to think it ever is what goes around always comes back around and you will get your turn soon ” this way my kids don’t expect to get something when others get something they don’t get sad at bday parties they don’t have a false sense of entitlement they’re genuinely happy for each other when they get something cool this takes time and patience and possibly tears in the beginning but it’s well worth it

i understand i have a complainer as a daughter she's and has gotten better but she still whines i have learned the power of headphones and ignore drives her nuts she knows onces i sit down on the couch and put them on she has lost all hope now this didn't happen over night this took many many days of trail and error try things out you will find what works once it clicks you will be like that worked wow sorry about your start i had it bad too abusive parents i swore i was going to be the opposite of them so far so good i don't yell no physical punishment and we do things in my house different you need to find your way keep a small notebook take notes write some stuff down we broke that cycle it's time to start fresh raise our kids with no fear of their moms we can do this i believe in you make time for just you and your daughter you and her coloring together watch her favorite movie together or her favorite tv show you and her do stuff together also before you go into any store give this a try okay we are going into the store to get a d c b we are not getting toys or junk food or this or that do not ask the answer will be no i still do this with my kids ànd they are and good luck you can do this i believe in you

my dad was big on no new stuff til x date and that worked well generally something like christmas birthday last day of school as for pay day i think you can gently explain that when you get paid your first priorities are the house food and clothes and pay day doesn't necessarily mean fun stuff for you or her

there's a book how to talk so kids will listen there are ways to say no without saying no maybe you can give her month for digital content she gets it on the first of the month meanwhile she can use a journal to write down the ones she likes if my son complained about another's birthday gifts i would suggest he start making some plans for his birthday or pick a school end present or a christmas present etc or i would remind him of something nice he's got coming his way like a playdate with a friend i tell my son beforehand not to expect a toy when we go to the store if he really likes something then i take a picture of it i have followed up so he does trust me for example he likes the model toy car displays at the pharmacy and we do sometimes have to go so i took a picture of one when with him but then bought it and gave it to him a couple weeks later when he got his report card it is a simple thing but i want him to be acknowledged and also to look forward with hope and also to be proud of the things he accomplishes i too am very annoyed when my son asks for stuff but it is normal i don't give in but i feel almost hurt when he keeps asking like he just doesn't appreciate me or our home i try to put aside the feeling and i have lots of techniques for saying no delaying gratification or setting limits

some valid points and great suggestions here just wanted to say though the fact that you're asking for help means you are a great mom you care you're probably trying to fill a void from your childhood so it's understandable and none of us know your parenting styles outside of this one issue so all of those judging really don't have a rock to stand on with the bonding thing maybe counseling will help not all kids parents need to have a super strong bond some are just vastly different personalities just love her and try and find some things in common and be a good parent bonds come and go as they age and roblox has an option to do a direct monthly withdrawal i do for my year old every month for helping feed water letting out the dogs that way he never asks outside of that monthly deposit hang in there you'll find someway to make it work

you need to read boundaries with kids cause it is extremely helpful stop telling your kids when you get paid yes she will cry when it’s her brothers birthday and she gets nothing but she’s coming to have to learn that she can’t get everything you make make it fun for her as well by making sure she’s also having some fun but even if you don’t do this she needs to understand that it’s her brothers day and not hers if she can’t clam down take her out of the party for a few minutes and let her clam down with you and alkyl explain what’s going on and that even though it’s her brothers birthday she is still loved don’t give in just because she’s crying or whining cause they want you to do something keep your boundaries

we went through this my wife was going out though divorce with her previous husband and working a lot so she spoiled her daughter out of guilt every day when we picked her up from grandmas she ask where her toy surprise was we weaned her off of it with very small things and then only occasionally and then none at all there was a lot of whining and crying and we were both scared she was permanently spoiled but eventually she got over it we talked to her about why we don’t get toys all the time about money all that you can get past this with her it’s just gonna require you to be firm and patient through her meltdowns about it try planning activities to do together to replace that space in the relationship with something more healthy and meaningful

my almost year old has been like this for about a year too i think it’s just the age they are testing their powers but also still lack the empathy self awareness etc to know that it’s not appropriate they obviously don’t have a good grasp on budgeting either 😂 we just try to stay firm but empathetic and we give him little opportunities to earn money by doing extra chores etc so can start understanding what it’s like to save up money for something he wants most of the time he ends up having fun doing chores and getting caught up in that stuff that it ends up being a good distraction it’s not useful as far as saving us work because he doesn’t do a great job but he likes to try to use the vacuum or spray and wipe things or use a duster so it keeps him occupied we still tend to spoil him a bit especially during covid and being stuck at home more but we’re working on it and he’s starting to catch on

as far as i read here on reddit this is a common problem now on school nip it the bud maybe this approach is worth a try put on your very worried voice and say oh no are you feeling ill are you in pain this moaning means either s*x or pain you are much too young for s*x so you must be really ill lead the child to his bed tuck him in close the curtains and take away all electronics with the words if you are so ill you really have to rest you stay in bed for today just rest for all meals bring him a bowl of intact chicken broth it is so good for an upset body don't give in to any responses always answer the moaning sounded so bad i am not taking any chances the next morning ask him if he feels better and wants to get up again tell him you will take moaning very seriously from now on moaning means illness if it continues you will take him to a doctor if this is a joke he will pay for any treatment tell him i will not allow underage s*x in my home if you make these moans when you are with a friend said friend will leave i will contact the teacher and if you moan in her class i will kut you in bed without electronics and lights out for days we will squash this horrible illness whether it is on purpose or not he is only so you could just omit some parts of these sentences the s*x parts because of age my son was when he had a short problem phase so reactions differ

letting kids pay for half of weekend trip i have two kids ages and this summer they have had a ridiculously successful lemonade stand they’ve averaged each day they’ve done it which has been about twice a week this summer they also get paid much less to do chores around the house so far they’ve spent their chore money each week on their own roblox or the ice cream truck but have a combined over saved from their lemonade stand our money was a little tight this summer because we’re getting ready to move we’re not struggling but vacation wise we haven’t done more than a few day trips and one weekend camping trip in years past we’ve also done a weekend trip to an amusement park about hours away with lodging that includes an indoor water park my kids have recently asked if we would be doing that again this year and i told them it’s not in the budget this year but maybe in the spring a few days ago they came to me and asked if they could pay for this years trip i’m really on the fence about it on one hand my husband and i could pay for half the trip to basically cover ourselves paying for half the trip would eat about half of their savings and we could offer to pay them back with an extra trip in the spring or just straight up cash they also don’t need the money for anything they already have savings accounts and i would rather them spend the money on a trip than candy or more toys that they don’t need on the other hand i feel like i’m exploiting my children would you let your kids contribute towards a vacation

i think it’s impressive they are offering and i think that would be a great way to show them how to earn money save it and use it on something positive plus i like the idea of adding an extra trip in the spring to basically say thank you for contributing to our family’s success kudos to you for raising great kids

i think this is not only a great idea i'd probably be against it if you pitched it but they were the one that approached you i also think it's a great life lesson get them involved talk about budget planning activities and maybe if you can work it in try to plan a secret surprise during the trip as a reward for their hard work and thoughtfulness

i would let them our daughters were and when they wanted to take their two junior high sweethearts now husbands on a beach trip by them paying for the extra room hubby in a room with guys gals in my room and they started going on family vacations with the parents of each future son in laws by them paying the cost of extra room with guys with dad in a room and daughters in room with the mom lots of fun and wonderful memories for all of us
let them pay kids need to feel needed and this is huge i’m very proud of your story and your kids perfect way to spend that money family trip and it’s their idea great family
side note but where the hell do you live that your kids lemonade stand makes a day lol
it was their idea they are choosing what to spend it on so i say go for it definitely pay them back if you can but dont feel bad about the trip

i’d put the half in that’s really wonderful your kids have worked hard & found something worth spending their money on you’re doing a really good job
let them do it it’s not like you’re forcing them to use the money for the trip it’s either no trip or they pay half the kids decide sounds like a win

this is definitely a learning moment let them have input on where you go what activities you plan etc show them prices teach them to budget look for deals make an entire project about it they’ll love it

wow no matter what you do you should be so proud of your little ones you’ve clearly done a great job raising them

am i a bad father i'll try to make this brief i have a year old son from a out of wedlock birth the mother and i have not been together for years i love on the other side of the country and i'm active duty military but let's not make the military a determining factor i pay child support and have visitation i get my son every spring break week every summer days every thanksgiving days and every odd christmas about weeks he has his own phone and calls me whenever he wants we don't talk everyday but at a minimum i try to make sure i call times a week we only video call so we can always see each other when we do talk on the phone it can range from mins quick good morning good night before bed to hours watching a show together or me watching him play roblox or us playing a game together we occasionally play phone tag due to my work schedule and his school schedule and most times i get off when he's about to go to bed and i sometimes miss my call window so i try to stick to calling on the weekends and days he's out of school the mother thinks i need to do more as a father like visit on unscheduled days like presidents day weekend for example the way i see it with the allowed pto leave time flight drive time cost for commute and lodging to do all of that just for a weekend doesn't exactly seem logical to me when instead i can save all the leave time and funds for my designated time i love my son very very much and i feel that i'm doing what i can when he's with me we do everything under the sun and he enjoys his time and so do i my son loves me and takes every chance to be around or something with me we play video games together we ride bikes together and talk about deep sea creatures and anime together which is something i know he loves b c he doesn't get that type of interaction at his house it's explained to me that i'm doing the bare minimum what more can i do at my distance am i a bad father

by your count you are parenting days out of a day year and calling less than half the week fact is you are a mostly absent father my siblings and i had a dad like that and that's just not enough time for you to be embedded in a kid's life the way a present dad is my brother was angry and would just complain about the travel time to see him and having to give up home time or time with friends to see him just to basically have everyone get to know each other over again every time i always wanted the limited time i had with my dad to be perfect so i was usually disappointed it also made me never talk about anything serious or deeply personal in my life because i didn't want to waste our fun time on being vulnerable or uncomfortable so our relationship became pretty shallow as i got older we never made up that ground in adulthood because he died somewhat suddenly

hey i'm your kid in the future growing up i only saw my dad for christmas summer and thanksgiving break we didn't have video calling and i don't honestly remember talking on the phone with him every week because he was a long haul truck driver i love my dad i always have our bond is good because like yall when we were together the time spent was very present and heartfelt as an adult with my own kids i question why he didn't call more often and play an active role in my day to day life not so much why didn't he visit more often my advice text him every day even if he doesn't respond and give him a glimpse into your life send random pics to let him know you're thinking of him a quick good morning and look starbucks has their christmas cookies out i'm sending your mom so yall can get some after school or ask him for his favorite songs so you can listen to them while you do stuff

my son's father moved to the other side of the country months ago he didn't have to he chose to i as the mom now operate basically on the same schedule as you dad has part of summer and alternating christmases and spring break he calls or texts approximately once a week my son has a phone and can call his dad anytime but he doesn't because his dad doesn't know anything about what's going on in his life because it's obvious he doesn't care you call him twice a week mostly on the weekends during what is likely his and his mom's only free time way to go dad what's the name of your kids teacher who is his best friend you pay child support is it enough do you even care have you ever asked or is it just the state guideline what does a school lunch cost or does his mom pack a lunch for him every day when was his last dentist appointment and when's his next one and are there any issues you should be watching for does he have enough properly fitting socks and underwear winter is coming does he need a coat what was hard at school for him today what was the last thing his mom had to punish him for does he need shoes do you know what size his feet are what's his favorite podcast right now is his mom experiencing any extreme life stresses where she could just really use from freaking help pretend you have to feed yourself and someone else three square meals a day every single day this and a million other things are what his mom is doing every single day all these people telling you that you are a great dad aren't parents or are just trying to be nice you aren't necessarily a bad dad you don't hit him it doesn't sound like but in no way are you a great dad find out the answers to all the questions i posed above and then stay current on them doordash your kid a meal so maybe mom doesn't have to cook for once because supporting mom even if you aren't in a relationship is part of being a good parent find out when the next parent teacher conference is and ask if you can attend via zoom spend time with him when you aren't doing everything under the sun make him bored and then deal with him you sound profoundly unaware of what parenting actually consists of
honestly the interactions are more like a fun uncle or older brother his mom is doing the heavy lifting of parenting and raising a child and you are more a playmate

you're not a bad father at all however i would suggest maybe flying your son out to you for long weekends you can arrange with the airline to have a staff member on to the plane & off that would give mom a break your son a mini aventure and you a bit more time with him to more hands on parenting if online school is still a thing he could even stay for a week at a time just an idea

my mom lived across the country from my brother and i for years we had a similar visitation schedule to what you described we called daily i knew that every day she was out there was a day she was choosing to be away from us it was a choice she made good money but i didn’t need her money i needed a mom parents aren’t present just for trips and fun outings mom probably feels all the stress of parenting… getting them off to school the bedtime routine taking them to extracurriculars and the fun parent gets so much credit because they don’t have to do any of the discipline i don’t think one more weekend of the year will make much of a difference in your relationship with your child mom might be jealous that you get it so easy you don’t put in any of the thankless daily labor yet you get all the credit for being the “fun parent” that would probably be how i’d feel the money and “logic” is not the right approach to this situation kids see who is there i resented my mom for a lot of years and we had to work on our relationship to repair things my brother never went through that he always adored my mom and still does but he was a little younger when everything went down your relationship might be fine with your son and if you’re okay with seeing him less than months of the year that’s your business my only suggestion is that you keep tabs on your relationship if he starts making passive aggressive remarks then what you’re doing now might not be working sometimes as kids get older they start viewing the situation differently make sure that you and mom don’t speak poorly of each other in front of your son you sound like a decent dad your son will have good memories of you two playing together i would encourage you to find a way to live closer to your kid you’re not married to the military your son is your blood and you will never get these years back i hope you want to be more involved because as a parent your role extends beyond wallet and playmate you’re more like a “cool uncle” right now in your level of involvement i’m glad that you want to have a good relationship with your son but parental duties are more than that what do you want to teach him what values do you want him to adopt how can you guide him through tough situations
yes you're a bad father

honestly being a fun relative you see every now and then does not equate to being a good parent i’m sure you guys have fun together but you can have fun with anyone doesn’t make them a parent i could not even imagine spending so little time with my children it’s not who i would want to be in their life and for selfish reasons too by the time they move out you are already going to have spent more than of all the time you will ever spend with them i’m already feeling the horror of when i wont be spending every day with them and they are currently both under two living in another town would be unthinkable another state even more so everyone is different i guess but i would have some major regrets down the line the older they get the less time they will have for you and the more time you will have for them don’t feel bitter in years when they only have time to see you a few days a year and don’t have time for any long calls their time will be limited and when push comes to show they will choose to spend the limited time they do have with the parent that where there every day sorry to be hard on you but i think you need a reality check

yeah you don't prioritize your kid and he knows that so does everyone else there are worse fathers in the world but imo it would be hard for me to respect a man that doesn't have his kid at least of the time barring some kind of extenuating circumstance like deployment or a some kind of medical condition or something many people change careers move cities or countries rearrange living situations i mean really go to the ends of the earth to be present in their kids' day to day lives so it's just about how much effort you want to put into it is your kid happy

this is a tough question and i guess that as you are asking you have reflected on your situation and are wondering if perhaps you are so the following is built on that premise you still need to work and live your life your needs wants and desires are important and no kid needs a parent that that blames the child for ruining their lives is there any reason your home base can’t be in the same city as your son noting i am aware military families often move around if you seriously want to be a dad and actually participate in your kids life then yes you should be spending every moment you can with the kid the kid is probably happy now but as he matures and goes through puberty not having you there is likely to be an issue for him i had to leave my state when my kids were mid teens for a couple of years it definitely changed the dynamic of the relationship i had with them if you truely want to be a father you also need to be talking to the mother as often as you can co parenting is tough damn parenting in general is tough but the mum is living with your son and will have insights into what is going on in his life that you just won’t have if you are serious be a parent and not just an adult friend your job is to help your kid be the best person they can be sometimes that means making hard choices in my opinion the relationship you’re describing with your son would probably best be categorised as an “uncle” type relationship you’re an adult in his life that has an impact on the type of person he grows up to be i put it that way because it sounds like you get to be the “friend” and have all the fun times but you most likely aren’t in the position where you’ll be the first person he goes to when he has a problem not saying what you are currently doing is wrong or that it will screw your kid up if it’s enough for you then go with it ultimately it’s your decision but as with all decisions choices you make don’t half arse it and make sure when you look back you can say “i did the right thing”

how long is your enlistment yrs have you been in the army his entire life do you plan on staying enlisted until retirement there will be times when life makes it necessary to physically be away from our kids that alone doesn't make you a bad parent but just cause you're calling and spending vacation time sure as hell doesn't make you a good one if you aren't going to change your life or lifestyle you just have to sort of accept you're not a great dad don't think you're a hero for what you're doing be honest with yourself some people have lives or traumas or finances or whatever that make them not great people it sucks that they hurt people along the way it sucks that you have missed out on a lot of important moments and a lot of unimportant ones it sucks that he will most likely always ache for you but that's been done you weren't a great dad you can acknowledge that you're doing the best you can and you aren't a good dad and you can still be a good and worthy person but moving forward what are you going to do what are you capable of and what's feasible are you okay with acknowledging this are you ready for the hard conversations when he's old enough to ask questions how will you feel far in the future having a son who you only know about on holidays

surprised i haven’t seen the term “disneyland dad” thrown around here basically the fun superficial dad it’s good while they are young but when they get older they start to see it for what it is i do believe unfortunately your ex is right and it is bare minimum there is so much involved in raising a child you’re missing it i am sad for you but also sad for your son when he grows and has his own family he will discover how much you weren’t there your relationship will always be this way unless you choose to do more during his formative years you don’t have enough “credit in the account” to make it through the constant emotional withdrawals that come with having a teenager teenagers are rebellious stubborn angsty argumentative etc you trying to “parent” or discipline him when he gets into this stage will likely feel laughable to him like you’re choosing to parent now when you have chosen not to their whole life i say this as someone who had a mostly phone conversation and some weekends and holidays with a parent it will feel like oh now you want to show up and unfortunately i still get the ick from this parent even though we do have a decent relationship as an adult their affection and desire to be involved in my life now feels gross and unnatural to me and i am a grown woman in my mid s when things get tough he is going to turn to his mom his whole life and when you’re old that may hurt your ego and you may wish you did things differently but it will be too late it’s great you are being reflective there’s a lot of good advice here and also a lot of excuses as to why it’s fine to continue the way you are

i was a kid who lived on opposite side of country from my dad not military from ages + our visitation schedule was very similar to yours it was the s so video calls weren't an option but we had a weekly phone call sunday nights the only thoughts i have on what you can consider does he always come to you my dad has come to where i live times in years that has been a negative for me when your son comes to you how focused on time together are you or do you just go about your usual routine it sounds like you probably are hyper focused on the visit which is good but if not think hard on whether he may feel unwanted or like an inconvenience if you are just going about life while he is there ie taking pto to work on house projects and he is spending significant time by himself

i had a dad exactly like this and we have a super awkward and not close relationship now when we do talk it’s fine but i also have a son and i can’t imagine only seeing him a handful of times a year i feel like i barely know my dad he feels like any other distant family member i often wonder what my relationship with my dad would look like now if he had come around more he’s not a bad guy at all but he was the most proactive luckily i had a great stepdad who was there who became a strong father figure so i don’t consider myself a girl with daddy issues no hate to you you seem like you want to do more and are willing to but i’d jump on it now before he becomes a teenager and wants to spend his summers doing other stuff good luck

you are not a bad father my dad also military lived in virginia japan and even miles away from me after him a my mom got divorced when he lived in japan he complained that he had to pay for half of my ticket to visit him when he lived miles away i didn’t even know me and my sister saw him driving down the street and we followed him home that’s how we found out he never tried to see us or invite us over on my th bday he called my mom to tell her he was taking her back to court so he could get his child support lowered she asked if he wanted to talk to me happy bday and he said no she asked if he was coming to my graduation the next day and he said he wasn’t planning on it because he didn’t know if i was graduating i got a college scholarship so that was a bs excuse that’s what a bad father looks like

i think effort is the determining factor ask others have said ask yourself if you’re doing more than minimum are you doing the best you can right now considering all factors of your life if the answer is yes i think it’s good enough the only thing that popped into my mind was maybe start writing your son letters i know you guys talk on the phone and visit when you can when scheduled but writing a card or hand written letter is something that takes time and effort and isn’t a monetary gift like you aren’t trying to buy his love or send him gifts all the time no one wants that it’s a clear effort to show you were thinking of him at a time he wasn’t available couldn’t talk on the phone or you were on a work break and he’s at school and you took the time to write this down put a literal stamp on it and mail it across the country maybe find cool postcards to send him and no i’m not old 😂 i’m and i just think this is a cool way to show your effort without expecting reciprocation from him just a little extra thing you can do if traveling to him isn’t an option effort even small things goes a long way

i’m not a service member but i am married to one i can completely understand where you’re coming from with the holidays unless you live relatively close because getting flights etc approved can be like jumping through hoops or it not even getting approved especially if you have a crappy command i also know that the military does like to make last minute changes and the pay isn’t absolutely incredible so wanting to save and be prepared for when he does visit to make it as memorable is completely understandable it’s not like you can just up and move either you’re required by orders to be at a specific location and i think alot of people forget about that and you may not be given the option to choose where that location is i think you’re being as involved as you can be i’d just say take every opportunity to call when you can maybe send him a little care package or something of his favorite snacks the two of you enjoy sharing or some of his favorite little knick knacks to show you’re thinking of him and remember those are his favorite things you can’t be faulted because you have a contracted obligation to a job that you can’t just call out of like others can while it may seem to others like you’re doing the bare minimum i feel like you’re doing the most you can at the end of the day as long as you and your son have a great relationship that’s all that matters edited to fix a sentence mistake

yes this my dad was army my brother was army i was army and i currently work for the army as a civilian it is *absolutely* a factor and there's no use pretending it's not you can up and walk away from a regular job if it's interfering with your ability to be a present parent you can just wander off the job site one day and never come back move to be closer to your son assuming you otherwise have the means to do this and get yourself a new job where you're going to be living and there are no consequences other than the regular day to day difficulties of doing those things the army *is* a completely different world in this regard and it's silly to try to treat it as though your long distance situation is the same as anyone else's so now you have to ask yourself since my army career is interfering with my ability to be a present parent to my son what am i going to do about it request a reassignment to a different post to be closer retire if you have enough time in resign your commission if you're an officer refuse to reenlist and go ahead and ets when your contract is done nothing you have options your choice is going to boil down to what your priorities are this isn't me criticizing you just helping you understand none of your choices are wrong but they will all have different consequences and you have to decide what you can live with is your army career the priority so you can ensure you get a pension+va so you can have tricare for life and always have income no matter what that's a valid choice but it may irrevocably stunt your relationship with your son and ex are those relationships more important and you decide to get out of the army to be present for your son also a valid choice but you'll be sacrificing quite a bit to do so obviously i don't know you or your life and i don't know what your choices really are these were just examples but the point is nobody ever said parenting was easy we all have to decide how to approach it and what our roles and priorities are going to be good luck sincerely

i am not military but i think this is helpful information also i’m surprised no one has said it or as far as i have seen what about asking your son what he wants keeping in mind that if he wants to move to be with you that you are willing and able to provide that opportunity for him also for what it is worth i think you are a good father just for asking the question you obviously care enough to put yourself out there for complete strangers to assess i would encourage you to communicate with mom and find out why this is coming up if she has been fine with the arrangements thus far maybe there is something else going on with her communication is the only way to have any sort of relationship whether it be parenting or coparenting i would say that it basically boils down to what you can live with even if you are not physically present there are ways to be there for your child most schools have electronic ways of communicating with parents are you able to receive the day to day school information like maybe if there are field trips or something you can arrange to help out in some way providing lunch or something if there are discipline issues you could help to navigate that be there by video for the tough questions maybe help out with homework when or if possible i would encourage you to try and have the best coparenting relationship in order to be as present as possible maybe it is something as simple as y’all ordering or making the same meal and eating together via video chat on a week night i don’t presume to know you or your life i can’t say what your priorities are but you know you know your priorities and your integrity that is what it boils down to are you the type of father that makes your son proud are you proud of the type of father you are these are just some things to think about in closing i commend you for caring enough to ask the hard questions i thank you for your sacrifice for our country i truly wish you well

as someone with both parents in the military and extremely involved maternal grandparents… i would note that the time you listed is mostly the “fun time” spring break summer etc you’re not doing any of the most difficult showing up of life homework sick days cleaning cooking healthy meals lunch packing taking him to extracurricular etc you’re not a “bad father” you’re just absent for a lot of the day to day grind he might not notice it now although he might but he definitely will as he gets older he’ll want your presence at his sports games concerts etc life is the day to day not just the big moments as he becomes a teenager it will be more difficult to overcome arguments because he can simply hang up i mostly remember my parents not showing up and they definitely were there for the “big stuff”… but honestly as an adult it was the cinnamon toast when i was sick from my grandma that i miss or my grandpa teaching me to ride a bike i love my parents deeply but hands down it’s the day to day i live on the other side of the world now and don’t visit that often just for the fun times… but i know it’s the day to day that counts and it’s really sad he will only be a child for a few more years if you can be local it would probably create a stronger foundation

if your goal is to be a father and just an overall good parent i think you should be working towards being closer to your child more often having my dad around during planned visits or going to his house for the summer or whatever it was like visiting a relative we did fun stuff he lived in florida we always went to theme parks and stuff it was an event in the most ideal situation parents are there most of the time they're available and present in the mundane times and during the exciting times they provide a kind of consistent stability of being there to guide and to reassure and to comfort and to seek care from that kind of attachment is really important and again i don't think you can really form that kind of attachment with the way your setup is currently when i was a kid i wanted my dad around i just wanted him there i missed him i wanted to share my life with him like i could with my mom my life was where i was when i went to where he was it wasn't the same nothing was mine nothing felt like mine again it was like going on a vacation what if i had a hard day and just needed someone to be with me can a video call replace that i don't know we didn't have that when i was a kid it wouldn't give me a chance to have my friends know my dad though or take me somewhere after school to be comforted like if you were there think about how many opportunities you would have for connection which are impossible the way things are as a parent sometimes the little things make the biggest difference how connected do you want to be with your child if you really want to be connected you need to be closer more often

i think the distance is really the kicker here you sound like you're doing the best you can and as someone who grew up with my dad only minutes away but completely out of communication i'm going to say i think it's awesome you call frequently and awesome that you commit to your schedule this stuff is so important and helps your son feel loved and supported and that is super important the flip side of this equation is that mom may be feeling a lot of stress you get your son during his down vacation time mostly so the brunt of the work is still likely falling on her and she may be feeling frustrated by that things like helping with homework every day teacher conferences keeping up with after school activities getting kiddo to birthday parties and keeping up with all that that's likely mostly on her and it gets really tiring especially if she feels like she ever has to be the strict scheduler manager or bad guy in terms of schoolwork or discipline there's a very real phenomenon of the disney dad mom has to be the disciplinarian and taskmaster then dad shows up for vacation time and everyone just has fun i would suggest if you haven't already really looking over how things are working to make sure you've got some of the less fun stuff too when you call over the week are you helping him with or looking over his homework when he's visiting you over the summer are there teams he can play on or music lessons or whatever that he can do while with you so you're handling some of that stuff too are you able to meet his teachers and do virtual conferences with them etc it may be you're doing a lot of this too i don't know the full brunt from your post but it's something to keep in mind i can tell you really want to do the best you can and you are already making sure you are connected to your son and love him very much and your ex may always be biased in this regard i just wanted to bring up this dynamic so you can pay attention and make sure you're not slipping into it
