it is normal if you let them but like anything too much isn't good for them at he needs to be using his imagination and playing it's a parents job to limit addictive things like video games

i mean i hope i don't sound condescending but the way to circumvent that is to limit or not allow screen time you'd be amazed the kind of stuff they'll find to do if you just leave them alone and let them get bored

single gamer mom of an year old boy couple things limit screen time my kiddo is autistic so we have it tied to a reward point system we were struggling with him viewing video games as a right not a privilege so this helped both limit screen time and teach him he can't just fill his day with a game screen time is actually ok if it's productive learning doesn't count as screen time for us coding games math games online comic makers etc nor does his virtual minecraft social group my kiddo is autistic so this social learning group is a real boon last thing here's a hot take i wish more people understood *it is good to be bored * being bored is a skill it teaches us how to live with our fucking thoughts be creative gives us an opportunity to daydream shower thoughts they happen because we are unoccupied being bored is a skill that needs to be developed when my kid comes to me and says he's bored i give him three things he can do if he doesn't want to do any of them i tell him to practice being bored idk a out anyone else but my parents were busy and poor and i was always bored and yet our impulse as parents is to give our child something to do did being bored as a kid damage me no i'm fine also i'm not talking about neglect don't neglect ur kids please but a healthy boredom is fine if anyone feels like they need permission here you go it's ok to let your kid be bored

video games are amazing tools i played so many video games for so long as a kid and i've done just fine as an adult i haven't played roblox but minecraft is fantastic for learning all kinds of things my year old plays it all the time and we use it to teach her about planning architecture animal care and a whole lot more and she's built some really cool things we also play rayman together and she's learned about team work and incremental improvement which has helped tremendously as she's started learning to read when she gets frustrated we just say remember how you thought you'd never beat that one level then you practiced it over and over and then you got good enough to beat it and she immediately perks up and starts trying again if you don't like the games he plays help him find options you're ok with games like planet zoo are fantastic at teaching about everything from how to care for animals to budgeting to design

completely normal for an year old to want to play video games all day my friends son is like this her answer he can play for a few hours but then has to come off and have a few hours doing something non screen based if he moans or complains his time on the screen is reduced the next time he goes on games he soon learned not to moan and to get a good balance hope this helps

i am going to go against the grain here just cut screen time is a rather stupid response you have an year old and you expect him to entertain himself for hours alone of course he goes for the interactive option it would be a videogame issue if he was picking screens over playing with you or with other kids that would be a reason to limit screen time but telling an year old kid to entertain himself then taking away the one mildly entertaining thing there is either put in the effort to play with him or to get him to places with other children or let him play games my kid is bored off his mind and is using the only interactive medium to his disposition just cut it away so he is bored enough to go with the more boring options saddening really

piano practice my daughters have piano lessons twice a week for min each time and don't practise at home in between unsurprisingly they are stuck playing the same tunes for longer than necessary i promised myself that i wouldn't nag them to play in the same way my parents forced me to practise daily but not saying anything isn't the solution either they get sulky when reminded gently from time to time to practise any thoughts on how to motivate them i feel i am being too soft with them but my husband doesn't say anything to them so it feels as if it is my battle to fight alone surely i can't have them playing roblox or whatever when they come home from school thanks in advance for tips advice

i never wanted to practice either but it helped if there was a set time every day that i needed to it was much harder when it could be at anytime i’d consider establishing a schedule with them then you hopefully will have to remind less if it’s established that they are expected to at x time

do they have an interest in it i'd do set practice times where you or hubby can be near and encourage guide for example when my son practices his guitar i will be doing dishes or cooking and i'll pop in occasionally to say wow that is sounding great or it's ok it's a frustrating bit take a little break and come back to it i think too after school isn't a good time nor closer to bed give them some complete veg time after school to snack and just be you might be doing this already but i thought i'd mention it since you said you don't want them on roblox after school if you are approaching them when burned out you'll get grumpy gus times out of

find them songs they'd be interested in i played piano for years before i figured this one out go on youtube and find piano transposes of their favorite songs you can usually find some that are beginner friendly and most youtubers give their sheet music for free or for sale they can also go find music themselves that they might like maybe they don't want to play bach but like to try debussy if they're real beginners it'll be pretty tough to do but past like intro to piano you should be able to find music sometimes you just don't feel like playing baroque music when you're a teenager lol

as a music teacher myself i would not recommend that any of my students do lessons twice a week once a week for an hour okay for some students it doesn't give them enough time to practice and imo compounds the issue of getting stuck on the same piece in my experience the biggest obstacles to practicing and improvement are not having a fun element to their lessons or to their practicing practicing incorrectly and trying to practice too much or trying to cram practicing shorter amounts of time practicing daily are better than longer amounts occasionally i would suggest talking to their teacher if you haven't already about good practice habits if they're just playing through the entire piece over and over for example it won't help them get better lastly practice sessions should always end with something fun a piece they have already mastered and enjoy playing their own composition a popular song they like etc good luck

my m sons best friends are online hi all my son is only child and he is struggling to make friends at school and has made a group of buddies online with similar interests that live in other countries i worry that this is problematic for him to prefer these friends over his irl friends more details i apologize for the length my son is great his special interest is history more specifically military history he had a core group of buddies growing up but now that they are in middle school everyone has dispersed and gone their own way my son is now having a hard time relating to other kids his age he started playing roblox a few years ago and he formed a little “club” of what i am hoping are other kids and they all build and play world war games together there’s one kid in particular who he has bonded with a lot the kid lives in another country as do most of the kids in his club my son says that these kids are his best friends and are the only ones who he has common interests with i’ve vetted these online kids as much as possible i’ve read roblox conversations with them and it all seems like normal kid talk recently they did start a chat on discord so i’m monitoring that and again just seems like year old boys sending each other memes his best friend in the group sent a voice message last week to the whole club and it sounded like a year old boy it makes me sad he doesn’t have friends in real life covid was hard for him and very isolating since then he’s gotten closer with these online friends and i don’t know if this should be concerning to me i’m glad he has kids to relate to but it’s starting to get to the point where my son comes home frustrated every day because he says he’s “sick of the other kids” at school it’s making me concerned and he has suffered from anxiety in the past because he tends to go very hard on himself with school work he’s a perfectionist academically he excels he has straight a’s and has made honor roll every quarter he is starting a chess club at school and is participating in a geography competition this weekend i’m so proud but i worry about his preference for his online buddies over his real friends should i be concerned is there anything i can do to better monitor his online interactions or vet these friends eta please be kind i’m a single mom working full time with autism and i am doing my best and everything i can to make sure he’s ok i don’t want him to be lonely but also don’t want him to isolate himself i am in the process of finding a therapist for him but there’s always a wait his teachers say he’s doing great and his school counselor checks on him every month and reports back to me she says he’s a delight but he comes home annoyed and angry every day
of my boys have really good friends online one is tomorrow and one is in a few months their friendship is no less real just because it's at a distance

my youngest daughter went through a stage like this she was also a straight a student and i worried that most of her friends were online and all of that however she gradually started to come out of that phase she’s in her first year of university and has a very full social life and lots of friends she’s still a gamer though and still has online friends and will often game with them all night not all kids have the ideal social circle at secondary high school and my youngest didn’t really spread her wings until uni in that way we had a tutor for her when she was doing her a levels and she told us her experience was also the same and she didn’t really have that until she started uni either i wouldn’t worry too much as long as he’s bringing home the grades i also found that enrolling my daughter in tennis lessons really helped and she enjoyed it and it extended her circle a bit at the time xx

for the first several years of my son's screentime we made him 'pay' for it we had a poker chip system where he could give us a differently colored chip to get red minutes of video games blue hour of video games or white minutes of tv we provided a weekly allowance of chips and he could earn more based on good behavior or completing chores i totally recommend it in case you need something like this it teaches economics time management and respect we don't need to use them anymore but he remembers our updated rule is the rule no electronics before or after the daytime 's this helps mitigate the urge to break out the tablet before school in the mornings or way too early on weekends as far as video games are concerned i recommend having as clear a line of communication about being in control as possible **the moment you suggest it's time to turn off the video game it needs to turn off ** conversely as an adult i recommend *being sensitive to their needs as a gamer* make sure you check that they've _had an opportunity to save_ without abruptly turning off video game systems cuz that kind of stuff can stick with a kid for their whole lives i still remember my mom setting me back hours of zelda progress my son was raised on video games he taught himself to read from pokemon and is the best reader in his school feel free to let me know if you have any questions about games and kids

gamer parents are your kids prone to obsessive focus on a single game i probably know the answer because i know the amount of kids that incessantly play roblox or minecraft but it’s really interesting to see the varied behavior in my children i have one who plays a bunch of different games switches games during his minute playtime but i have another who is one game that shifts based on release maybe and it becomes the subject of his offline pretend play first it was rocket league then splatoon and now fall guys it’s all he plays the others become dead to him and he uses cars or stuffed animals when not playing to recreate the games it’s interesting to see but also a big worrisome any thoughts

mine tends to have one as her main jam like she'll go through a week or two of really wanting to play just dance most of the time or minecraft or animal crossing or whatever but she'll often do a bit of one of the others and so far i haven't overheard her barbies or playmobil families doing any minecraft expeditions intense focus on one game doesn't seem that bad in *itself* but if this kind of thing applies to schoolwork or makes him too inflexible when playing with others it could be something to check out i guess like any behaviour if it messes with the rest of his life that's when it would need addressing

that sounds really hard i was going to suggest a second opinion but i guess you're kind of stuck either way if there's no way to get her evaluated right now i still wouldn't punish her though if anything it will make her hate school and learning even more i know you said you have tried apps and programs already so my next thought since she likes roblox was maybe trying to find a game that involves simple math for her to play but i'm sure you've already tried that i'm not sure what kind of math rd graders are doing these days so i'm referring to the khan academy rd grade math course for ideas maybe instead of sitting and doing worksheets you could try to make it visual or tactile like cutting a circle into pieces to show fractions or using pompoms or something else small to do adding subtracting division multiplication making big shapes out of tape on the floor and using a ruler to measure to teach perimeter and area using different sized measuring cups and colored water to teach volume etc maybe if you can make it fun and engaging she can learn the concepts more easily and won't be as upset about completing her work when she understands it better for reading writing maybe try to go with her interests if she really loves horses for example find books about horses or kids horseback riding and read with her alternatingpages or paragraphs for writing you could find some simple writing prompts and take turns writing sentences to make a story then maybe even have her draw some pictures and get it printed and you could read that together too try to follow her interests as much as possible and engage her as much as you can school may still be a sticking point but i know that kids who feel they have fallen behind often end up hating school because they don't understand the concepts and feel like they're not good enough maybe if you can help her to build up her skills she will be more able to keep up in school and end up hating it less it must be very intimidating to her to sit down with you with a paper in front of her of things she doesn't understand and be told she needs to finish the work on it before she can do what she enjoys try to make learning fun for her but also hopefully you can get her evaluated sometime soon since there probably is some underlying issue that is making this so hard for her good luck and i hope you and your daughter find a way to make learning a positive experience for her

how do we safely support our son in starting game streaming becoming a yt gamer our son has talked about becoming a game streamer or youtuber for years literally actually at the start of the pandemic now that i think about it *preface we monitor his gameplay and all of his accounts are age restricted to teen level games he's also not allowed to play roblox for more than an hour a day because we think it's a toxic game that makes it easy to prey on children and this rule has made it easy for him to stop playing it organically as much * he's an avid gamer loves playing on his tablet switch and xbox and he also loves playing games that are very popular for streaming fortnite rocket league minecraft to name a few of course he follows his favorite youtubers who stream that content and has developed the desire to do the same thing while i m myself am an avid gamer and i love to game with him i'm not much into the streaming culture so naturally i don't know much about it i do know there are child youtube gamers out there and i know that nothing is without risk so my question is how can we help him fulfill his dream to start streaming his gameplay in relatively safe way i'm getting ready to gift him my old pc that has a decent graphic card on it and can handle the task of streaming if he pleases so i just want to make sure i'm prepared with whatever i might need while also keeping him safe any advice is appreciated

tell me how you have successful school mornings new to kindergarten this year kiddo reaaalllllyyyy struggles to get moving in the morning we wake him up at to get dressed brush teeth and eat breakfast everything else we do for him fill water bottle prep lunch etc we have to be out the door by to catch the bus we have a sunrise alarm clock clear routines and expectations and bedtime is around pm we are at the point now that he resists every little thing takes minutes to get dressed takes another to brush teeth and he isn't doing a good job brushing either this morning he took too long and missed breakfast i gave him an oatmeal bar on the way to the bus stop i literally had to dress him in his shoes and coat so we wouldn't miss the bus so hit me with your best tips edit thanks everyone for your replies seems like the general consensus is earlier bedtime rise time we will adjust hopefully it helps good to know we aren't alone with sleepyheads in the morning

minutes is a really short time for a young child to get ready why not go to bed a bit earlier and get up earlier it might save you a lot of stress we work with a chore list and a timer that shows how much time is cut out for each task it helps my daughter to stay focused but by getting up a bit earlier she also gets a grace period if she doesn’t make it if she does finish everything on time she can play or watch netflix until it’s time to leave

i think you need to pause your expectations for a moment he's only kindergarten he's still little and this is a big transition year i would expect all of the things he's doing to happen because they sound normal for that age speaking from experience as i have an yo boy my older son is now in second grade and this is the first year we've achieved independent mornings where he gets all the things done in a timely manner independently to make things easier on yourself i'd try moving his bedtime back to pm and moving wake up time to am this gives you an additional minutes to achieve everything without that feeling of rushing i think your main issue at this point is just time you probably just need more than an hour to get it all done for context my yo has hours before school to get himself dressed brush his teeth make and eat his breakfast work on his homework packet make his lunch and pack his backpack he gets it all done with around minutes to spare before school so he can reward himself with roblox lol but again he isn't rushed and he is in nd grade it took a few years to get to this level of function

i would wake up earlier and earlier until the routine works and that means likelly going to bed earlier our routine explicitly contains play time of about min when he will be older and will understand he needs to be out the door at a certain time i will of course let him sleep more and move faster i prefer that way myself

i wake my year old up at to be out the door around she is a slowpoke in the morning maybe try getting yours up a bit earlier help him brush his teeth so it gets done faster and more thoroughly get his lunch and water bottle ready before he gets up or the night before these are things that work for me and if we’re running late it’s usually because i lost track of time and started getting myself dressed and makeup on too late

i have a kid that is not a morning person and slow moving no matter what time of day so i allow hour from wake up to walking out the door for our morning routine wake up at breakfast get dressed then hair teeth and shoes and out the door between i’m not a morning person either so i respect they’re not either it means my alarm goes off at so i can have minutes to wake up on my own before jumping out of bed i’ve always had to allow more time for the kids i hate rushing in the morning because then i just feel like i’m constantly rushing and can’t catch my breath

school breakfast or breakfast in the car i do not even attempt breakfast at home she would take too long and her sleep is more important i physically help her with getting dressed and brushing teeth she has adhd at night she does these things by herself slowly in the morning we just don’t have time

dress him the night before unless he has a lot of night time accidents that has helped us at times it's better now and we don't have to do it but we did for a while keep it to very simple breakfasts keep the same routine on weekends even if you are not out the door

the struggle never ends however what made things less stressful for everyone was how i handled it no yelling just firm “we’re going this now now time for this now this go do this” i’m not a morning person so i reaaaalllly had to put my own issues aside to make sure my son has a nice morning and doesn’t get anxiety about the mornings being consistent is key and like another commented mentioned move the wake up time until you see it’s working out

almost year old but we can be out the door in less than minutes i pack her bag and lunch and set out her clothes the night before while her dad is reading the bedtime story and getting her in bed in the morning it's potty get dressed eat a nutrigrain fruit bar while i brush her hair then socks and shoes i throw my clothes on husband fills water bottle fresh and puts bento box lunch with cold pack in her lunchbox and grabs all the bags then we're out the door if we're super late she eats in the car if she gets up an hour or more before we need to leave then it's potty watch an episode of something while she eats a fruit bar and cheerios while i make my morning smoothie then shares the smoothie with me then pretty much the rapid routine at t minus minutes to leave i set timers for each stage including the grab your bags and out the door in minute warning
you need to get up earlier unfortunately that's not enough time
you'll achieve this a day after their senior graduation the struggle is real and kids will be kids

what works for us is using a little tv as incentive so he has to go potty get dressed eat breakfast and then he gets a bluey episode if he takes too long then we don't have time for tv if he does then we watch an episode then it gets turned off and we get hat gloves jacket on and we're out the door

we have a st grader and a kindergartener the night before we make their lunches and lay their clothes out on the couch downstairs when they wake up they have alarm clocks they come down eat a quick breakfast of cereal or yogurt get dressed and then i brush their teeth so that it's done thoroughly of course some mornings are smoother than others but we're on a much better routine now than we were last year when they were younger and less capable
that’s not a super long time an hour makes a little more sense maybe an earlier bed time ours is p and an earlier wake up time a out the door by a

some one else on here posted this tip a little while ago and it’s been a game changer in my house i don’t remember who otherwise i’d credit them we set up morning routines on our alexa and it’ll basically conduct the kids through their entire morning routine and set a timer for each thing like “c nb and i kids names time to get dressed or “time to brush teeth ” and then i can allot times for each action in the app and it’ll go off and instruct when it’s time for the next thing you can also set a playlist to it and have it read things like weather and traffic report we also try and do as much as possible the night before so set out outfits put everything in their backpack pack lunch pick waterbottle etc if they finish early they get play time until it’s time to go which is in an incentive to get everything done

for a kindergarten child i think he needs more time i also wouldn’t expect a kindergarten child to be able to do any of that alone you could make a “get ready corner” and put everything he needs for the next morning in this corner the night before including his outfit shoes underwear bagpack waterbottle coat

i figured out my guy hates to be rushed as soon as we start hurrying him along he digs his feet in so we get him up an hour or more before we need to go let him have to first mins to lounge and wake up as we discuss brekkie options he eats and i give him verbal heads ups like okay bud mins until we get dressed until we need to go we also use our google alexa for timers so he has a sense of control and the time passing it has really helped we also moved bedtime up a half an hour so it's not so hard to get him out of bed at bedtime was now it's

my kids are so slow in the mornings they need hour minimum to get ready preferably hrs some things i used to do or still do on rushed morning are getting the younger one dressed in their kindy clothes the night before as pjs and pack breakfast boxes to eat whilst driving commuting pack absolutely everything for them and myself the night before so i can focus on getting us ready quicker

it takes time this is new to him and he's still adapting my times are a bit different than yours but it looks like the amount of time is about the same my son wakes up at am and his bus comes at we're close enough to the bus stop that as long as we're already walking out the door the bus can pass our house and he'll still make it on the bus although we try not to do that something that helped my kiddo in the mornings is giving him choices where no matter what he still has to choose to do the thing but it's on his terms when he chooses something then he gets more options until it's time to move on to the next thing we also use a timer for some things like eating breakfast or picking out clothes or something that we know he can dawdle on an example of our morning wake up me do you want to eat breakfast first or get dressed first him eat breakfast m pancakes or cereal h pancakes m okay do you want to watch phineas and ferb while i make them or do you want to pick out your clothes h phineas and ferb m here are your pancakes you have ____ minutes to eat and here's your timer do you want me to pick out your clothes while you eat or do you want me to get your backpack ready h backpack m okay i'll get your backpack ready you pick out your clothes when the timer is done m okay timer is done time to pick clothes h i'm not finished eating m that's fine pick out your clothes and get dressed and then you can finish eating do you want pants or shorts short sleeve or long sleeve dino socks or dino socks rain boots or vans when you're dressed i'll set the timer for another minutes to finish eating when the timer goes off it's time to brush teeth m okay do you want the spiderman toothbrush or the t rex toothbrush etc i would say that it took us about months of consistency before it became really routine and no longer a struggle just before we let out for winter break we were so streamlined that he usually had about minutes to just sit back and watch some phineas and ferb before we had to walk out the door it doesn't always go that smooth but i'd say that it does more often than doesn't sometimes he decides to get dressed first on those days i usually just set his eating timer for minutes because he can watch the full first part of his p episode and then turn it off to finish getting ready i'm wondering if being off for two weeks is going to throw our system out of whack because i definitely didn't keep getting him up at am during break we're late sleepers usually

this all sounds perfectly normal for a kid that’s just not a morning person lol i have a year old that has me bracing for impact when it’s time to wake up and help through his morning routine and a year old that is usually up bright eyed and bushy tailed dressed and ready to go before i am every kid is different i’ve pushed our bedtime and wakeup earlier to give us more cushion in the morning i also try to set stuff like outfits and water bottles out the night before

honestly just stick to your routine and i think once kiddo realizes you won’t budge they’ll accept it thats kinda how it goes here and i have quite a defiant one just don’t give them wiggle room i also set timers and another thing is we used to have cartoons playing in the morning but it distracted him too much so we don’t do it unless he gets up early and gets everything done really early then i’ll let him do it until it’s time to leave that’s pretty rare though

so i have a child who started preschool with the township she's three and a half the bus picks her up around the corner at a m i wake up at to prep her book bag with her lunch and get her outfit ready i wake her up at to do her morning routine like using bathroom get dressed and do her hair i offer her a snack in the morning but she's also able to eat a snack when she first gets to school her bus ride is an hour at my husband gets in the car to drive over to the bus stop cuz it's cold now prior to that i was walking around the corner

this was a total fluke but something that worked well for my daughter when she was in kindergarten one day she was running so late that there was literally no time to brush her teeth so i told her sorry kiddo we don't have time for that today because it took so long to get everything else done hope the dentist doesn't find out or something like that it was mostly a joke because i was trying to be as nice as possible while not losing my shit trying to get her out the door but it worked the next day she got through her routine and brushed her teeth much faster and it's been so much easier since not perfect every day but hugely improved turns out that was a nice little example of natural consequences that actually worked

min is not enough time you are both feeling rushed and that always makes for a rough morning i would go to bed earlier and wake up earlier also create a checklist so he can see what needs to be done kids usually respond well to visuals lastly do everything you can the night before pick out clothes choose breakfast pack his backpack the less you need to cram in the morning the better

screen time i am curious specifically since the pandemic what is the average amount of time your little ones spend on their tablets when they are not in school or doing an organized activity my son can go hours straight if i don't intervene and make him play with his legos or take him to the park he is completely addicted to playing roblox and loves to do this with his other friends while they talk on kids messenger what are some techniques to limit screentime while i am working other than just taking it away

you are going to get a lot of responses from the screen time fascists here so here is something maybe closer to you… remember the virtual worlds our children are engaged in are amazing and they are also social outlets if when you were a child you had access to an amazing fantasy world that you and your friends could play in wouldn’t you be there all the time in our house we do a few things first we have daily chores so it doesn’t matter if you would prefer to be in your virtual world in your room you have to come out and do your chores second we try to create opportunities to do some things that are cool and fun and competitive we have one kid who really likes sports and she will leave her room to go play softball any day we have another kid who likes to go outside as long as somebody’s outside with him third we encourage some of the non gaming behavior we found out that two of our kids like to go on walks around the neighborhood and talk to each other so we adopted it made it kind of a rule hey guys it’s time to go on your walk and they do

my oldest is and we don’t really limit screen time too much my rule is she has to get dressed brush hair and teeth help with her chores read a few books do some math writing and play outside at least a hour everyday once those things are done she can have screen time i’d say typically she gets about hours a day of ipad tv time since summer break started usually broken up not all at once when she’s in school it’s closer to mins because she’s so busy with friends activities and school work i have a year old also and he does about mins of tv time total no tablet but he’s not really into it yet he rather play with some cars or blocks

we are currently in complete lockdown in our country and our son isn’t allowed to leave the house for the foreseeable future under lockdown rules even to go for a walk and we don’t have a backyard i initially was pretty strict about an hour a day but i’ve let up a bit and try to keep it to a limit of hours a day he’s limited to pbs kids only he still plays by himself and we work on plenty of educational things but at this point we’re all going stir crazy
my son gets minutes in the morings and another minutes in the evenings this works well for him but he isn't a very screen oriented kid

my kids and can have their phones as much as they want they spend a lot of time outdoors in the park with friends etc so i need to be able to reach them and they can also call me if they decide to go to a friend’s house or something so it’s not ”screen time” strictly speaking but anyway they are also into roblox and star stable and play those when they have time both also love to read and draw and do crafts so doesn’t seem like something i need to limit at the moment i’m also a gamer so i don’t have negative feelings about playing games as many people seem to have

our son is ten we have a lot of different games and systems for all of the downtime we've had because we move so frequently i will admit when the weather was especially crappy during lock down we had some extreme hours of technology use however we do have a rule where he can't just sit and veg on one thing if we are having a day where we stay home he needs to take at least a min break every hrs and at least one activity needs to be a family activity i e we watch a movie or tv show together or play minecraft together and no screens during meal time if it's nice outside we have him take his break by laying in the hammock and reading or drawing pictures or even taking a quick nap the reality is these kids growing up are going to be surrounded by tech there's no going cold turkey and changing that culture but i think giving them tools to understand moderation and how to unplug is a good idea
my and year old have minute limits my year old doesn't have a strict limit but keeps it under an hour the only exception is family movie night
my year old maybe has mins of screen time once in days we’re super strict about it we do a lot of outside time cooking baking reading books playing etc
love this post i feel like i am more liberal with the screentime rules as a year old tech executive who lives in a world of robotics and ai

screen time i’m curious everyone’s opinion on screen time and tantrums acting out lately i’ve noticed my just turned y o has been acting terrible and throwing tantrums and being all around nasty mean towards her little brother which she’s never done before i’ve heard from some people who cut out screen time for a couple weeks how their kids attitudes totally change but with kids one of which is a newborn it’s kind of our crutch we’ve cut it down already and will usually just watch a bit in the morning and then to wind down at night and then she plays roblox for an hour we cut that way down too but the attitudes just keep getting worse… just as a p s we’ve been trying to watch how we speak and i’ve tried talking to her about it but nothing seems to help also i do monitor what they watch very closely no tv on a phone or tablet it’s always on our living room tv so i know what they’re watching at all times

my y o twins act differently when it comes to certain apps they can spend a day resting watching netflix and they'll be happy getting up to eat and play around with their toys they had tablets and were a nuisance as one had a game the other didn't have so they'd argue over it to the point we'd have to intervene and take tablets away once we realised they were just watching stuff on it we accidentally on purpose forgot to charge them and we are almost months now without them now the worst is youtube it stopped almost instantly in our house they literally wouldn't move they'd piss and crap themselves and be completely hypnotised by it they'd go in a total meltdown if we even threatened to turn it off they aren't allowed to watch it anymore and we've had to warn the grandparents about it as last week both sets let them watch youtube and their behaviour afterwards wasn't great we don't mind them watching netflix and spending the day with the tv because by the end of the week they are burnt out but we do watch their screen time we don't put the tv on anymore when they get back from school and it's only them that will turn it on and it's a rarity

the type of show tends to be the game changer for our year old [turns in feb ] those horrible pimped out kids niki and vlad on youtube video where the people just holler and think they are funny kiddo is rude and has more meltdowns gabby's dollhouse bluey blippi mickey and jj minecraft videos where they fight zombies but also build shelters and use common sense to plan for a day shelter in place he's a good kid but i also think that some of the bad times that are better weeks later may sometimes be due to a growth period brain upgrade that finally ends rather than just reduced screen time i swear that the 'terrible twos' have nothing that was the intensity of the tantrums and rages we have seen a handful of times dueing year

yeah we don’t have any tablets and only our y o is allowed to play roblox for a certain amount each day all the other screen time is on the living room tv we also only let them watch two channels on yt anything else is disney or netflix i really think the issue might be roblox

yeah i learned about that a while ago and try to find “good” shows for them to watch ie storybots bluey i used to let her watch coco melon while i was dealing with her colicky baby brother but hated the way she would “zone out” and not respond to anything when she watched it i banned it after that lol

she’s actually good about getting off after the time limit we give her it’s just all the other time when she’s just playing with her brother during the day and stuff she’s talking back like never before crying at t he drop of a hat screaming at her brother for the smallest things it’s not all the time but it’s so much more than she’s ever done she never had a “terrible two’s” or anything like that as for roblox it’s very rarely the same game she plays she tries all different ones so i wouldn’t even know where to start with that the last days i’ve told her she can’t play at all which she’s accepted fairly well considering her attitude the rest of the day

wow homework in kindergarten that's some nonsense i would hate too i think he just needs more time to get used to it it's double the time it's a long day and i'm sure it's just different than what he's used to you can ask him what might help him would it be a picture of you to keep in his pocket would it be a watch so he can always see how much time he has left until he goes home

for the homework part honestly i never made mine do it not in kindergarten i always attempted to do it with them but if they were tired or burnt out or particularly fussy about it i didn't force it to me that's a lot to ask of a kindergarten kid everyday school and homework my kids did just fine in school ones an adult who went onto college one is in college and neither of my middle school aged ones fell behind i never had any of their teachers say anything about not getting their homework in everyday and i didn't have issues with them in the older grades doing their homework beyond the normal amount it's just a battle i refused to have at that age for the rest of it he's having a hard time adjusting that's normal at this age offer lots of comfort and hugs and it will probably pass in a week or two if it doesn't i'd revisit the issue but remember they pick up on our anxiety so try not to fuss on him too much

yes i would just give it time lots of big changes happened and it’s going to take a few weeks to get into the swing of things just keep encouraging him i like to ask my daughter what was the most fun thing you did at school today it helps bring up some positivity but man homework that sucks our school just started a new curriculum that is more play based and zero homework they realized how much the previous model was failing the kids unfortunately there’s not too much you can do about that at this point i’d take homework in small steps it’s kindergarten if he doesn’t finish it so what at this point start small get done what you can and as he gets into the groove of things up the goal of getting more done

can you volunteer to be a room parent even if it's once or twice it would give you visibility into the classroom goings on in the united states the accepted guideline which is supported by both the national education association and the national parent teacher association is the minute rule children should have no more than minutes of homework each day for each grade reached starting in st grade kindergarten = zero homework zero asking you to practice tying shoes with your kid is one thing asking you to read one book with your kid each night no big deal sending home multiple worksheets is completely different and i would straight up decline that so fast it would make their head spin i would take a printout of the homework guideline to the principal of the school and ask point blank why your kindergarten child is being given four worksheets of homework and no matter what they say you tell them we opt out of kindergarten homework thank you have a nice day <exit>

man this kid is getting some mixed messages in this house it is important for him to practice but if dad plays then mom tells him to stop it isn’t important mom is comparing him to his peers dad is comparing him to himself when he is neither he doesn’t have to play the piano time for a frank discussion not “do you want to keep playing” but “what do you enjoy about playing the piano ” it could be that he is bored of piano but not music or he likes it but feels like he is trying to meet your expectations which are too high etc if he enjoys music but is losing interest in the piano consider switching instruments maybe there is something new that he would like to try is a great age for guitar for example or drums make practice part of the daily routine get up eat breakfast get dressed practice for minutes before school get home from school practice for minutes before starting homework

hey there i also played the piano as a kid but resisted lessons and practice *a lot* i ended up continuing my piano education into my twenties and got the diplôme supérieur in the country i was living then and you know what i never really practiced all that much my technique was never really that amazing i mostly got by on passion and being into music and sheer confidence haha and the thing is somewhere along the way i discovered the reason i hated practicing those same goddamn bach pieces all day but also wanted my piano in my life is that what a really wanted was *to compose music * and the piano is an incredibly valuable available pathway to sit down and experiment with composition and improvisation and so on what does he like about the piano does he want to end up playing famous difficult pieces like you describe your own motivation being does he wants a way to express his feelings does he want to write his own music does he want to learn to accompagny like a vocalist or to play keyboard for a rock band does he want just enough mastery of the instrument to be able to connect to pop culture that way and interpret movie scores and videogame scores and stuff you'd be surprised how popular some people who just transcribe culturally relevant soundtracks into piano can be even when their performance technique is quite average; transcription is its own skillset what part of playing gets him ambitious and starry eyed he doesn't need to learn the piano in a rigid predetermined way just shape things around what interests and draws *him * and honestly he doesn't need to get good and work hard to deserve wanting to play

if he already had a good foundation to build on i would skip lessons for now and set him up with a piano learning app he can use that on demand and learn to play any song he likes my husband and i learned piano growing up and my kids took online lessons during the pandemic but they hated having another extracurricular activity at a set time we recently got a new piano and got a piano app on the ipad now everybody can sit down and learn a new piece when they feel like it the app also comes with lessons you can take we use flowkey but there are many other apps too this system is so much more flexible and by choosing the songs you want to play everybody is way more motivated to sit at the piano whenever they want

your wife needs to butt out she's getting way too involved in something that isn't about her your kid's friend's progress has nothing to do with your kid's progress motor development is a big part of musical skill and you don't know how else your kid's friend has been developing skills not only that but it *makes sense* for a kid to make rapid progress over their first year of learning because they learn the easy stuff first also your wife is probably *not* privy to the aspects of music that the friend is struggling with if she's seen him play or is going based on the friend's parents' bragging that will be focussed on the friend's strengths not his weaknesses she can't discourage you from playing and then expect him to play if you want him to value it you guys need to value it if you want him to practice the absolute best thing you can do is to model practicing and practicing bringing joy i'm tired is also sometimes a psychological defense mechanism against wasting energy on something he might be struggling with something like a musical skill he hasn't mastered but is required for the piece he's working on and need periods of deep rest to try to get it work can be happening in the brain even if it doesn't look like it don't make him stop his lessons just to punish him for not practicing the why am i wasting money on your piano lessons when you don't practice nonsense frames money spent on lessons as something that your wife expects to get a return on rather than something done for its own sake he's getting something out of his lessons so unless you're actually hard up due to them let him continue speaking of such any theory that he is learning in his piano lessons is probably being transferred to his violin playing which might explain why he's ahead

i'm not saying this is the best solution for your son right now but in general if you think there are issues with picking activities in the moment then you can use an alarm to help with the schedule and maybe just once a week for something like piano like if his lesson is on saturday then practice once on tuesday and set up the practice plan and alarm at the end of the lesson so it is easier to focus when the time comes also a benefit of this approach is if tuesday doesn't work then wednesday is the second chance day so it gives him structure in the scheduled time and the alarm to signal it and control just once a week some flexibility in the day this sets him up for success and then if he doesn't follow through put the lessons on hold for a few months after discussing it with him respectfully

>she also did tell him that she was a little disappointed that he did not argue back that time what on earth she's *disappointed* that he didn't *argue back* what is going on with this dynamic op i think you and your wife need to have some serious conversations about the things she's saying to your son if you want your son to have a meaningful experience learning this instrument the whole family dynamic around practicing needs to be reframed i played piano for many years practicing is not always fun and i think that's normal and okay i think pretty much anyone who's studied an instrument seriously knows that it's never going to be a completely pain free experience and that doesn't mean it's a bad thing sometimes you have to sit down with the metronome and drill something over and over and it's boring and annoying and you'd much rather go play or watch tv but the *overarching experience* of learning should be rooted in joy he should learn pieces he loves to play and that allow him to express his own individual artistry he should feel excitement and pride and inspiration and motivation from the process of working hard and getting better these are invaluable lessons for a kid it doesn't have to be fun every single time he sits down to practice but it also shouldn't be driven by shame or guilt or pressure to be better than his peers to save his mother from feeling embarrassed for god's sake

my son is almost and we have found that the stars don't work well for us they never really did it just jumbles up too many things we often use a daily checklist it gives him an idea of what is expected of him and if there is anything on the schedule it's just life not rewards when my son is defiant then i use the electronics for example if he can have an hour on the electronics then he loses minutes if he procrastinates if he's done with electronics for the day then it applies to the next day and i give my son a chance to earn it back well if you do your practice while i'm getting dinner on the table then i'll give you minutes on the electronics after dinner we use alarms and parental controls to help enforce it without too much confrontation in your case i think pausing the piano lessons is an effective consequence for not practicing i'm just trying to give a strategy for making the expectation much clearer tuesday at pm not whenever he feels like it i think it makes a big difference for motivation

experience with video game consoles for year olds my year old has been talking about wanting a video game console playstation preferably for over a year now he says he wants to do this because it gives him something common with his friends in school who all seem to have these consoles and are constantly talking about playing sports games fifa madden nba k etc he wants to fit in and i'm sure he wants to play the games too he and his year old brother already have ipads with roblox minecraft and a few other games which i lock down heavily and restrict to pretty short time limits with screen time the ipads have been a mixed experience they were quite educational for a while but then evolved into basically daily fun my kids at present are always out playing in the neighborhood or with team soccer i am kind of leery of video game consoles i presume i can lock them down just like ipads to particular time limits and games i'm worried that inevitably as the kids get older they will become giant wastes of time i didn't myself have a video game console until university although i had computers that could play games before that i watch zero tv and like to be out and about but i also want to be somewhat open to what my kid tells me is important to him for those who have experience with introducing video game consoles in this age range what has gone right and or wrong

there's actually a lot of benefits to video gaming as well even if it seems to take up more of your kid's time as they get older there's still lots of benefits here's a couple links to some studies that show the positive effects of video gaming of course i understand your concern surrounding it as kids still need to get outside and play and socialize in person but maybe this will help ease your mind in making your decision

i had and still have numerous video game consoles played a lot as a kid and play a lot as an adult my daughter was introduced to gaming at a very young age but it's always been instilled in her that gaming comes last after chores after homework after extra curricular etc her free time is her own and she can choose to do as she pleases during that time as long as everything else is done we don't even have time limits just as i didn't when i was a kid she's a straight a student who is doing ap courses taking pre college courses and calculus overall just a really good young adult i firmly believe that there are more benefits to playing video games than there are negatives but teaching kids how to properly use their time on their own first is a necessity

what do you do when you kid is losing their best friend my son is a higher functioning autistic so hes fine but weird he just told me minutes ago that he makes a noise in school “off” roblox character dying loudly and hes the only one that does it he’s also told me that his best friend from like the nd grade is kind of ditching him at lunch time so i worry about my kids he is currently seeing a therapist seen him about times so far really great guy it seems i'm going to bring this up with him and get his feedback i'm just wondering if any of you have dealt with this kind of thing

it's heartbreaking to watch your kids go through something like this but changing friends while in school k is a normal part of childhood adolescence i know personally that the friends i had in elementary school i was no longer friends with in high school though i had no animosity towards them and was still friendly with them when i saw them in the hall i just changed as i grew up and they did too

as the weird kid who got ditched the best things my dad ever did for me were make sure i never questioned for a minute that he loved me and not catastrophizing the issue while simultaneously not dimishing my emotions when i catastrophized i always new i had a solid support in my corner even though it's just not the same as friends and hanging out with your parents felt lame as hell when i was *it mattered * i knew i could talk to him about anything and he'd give his best input but never judge i also never felt like i made him feel bad or that he was overly anxious about things it helped me not be anxious too you know that's the emotional balance i'd shoot for supportive available but not overly anxious or concerned

i don't know what you should do but i know what you *shouldn't* do definitely don't do what my mom did when my best friend in middle school started phasing me out in favor of a more popular group instead of just supporting me as i assume most mothers would she encouraged me to be vengeful and conniving when my ex friend threw a party that i wasn't invited to my mom had the great idea to throw a party the same night and invite all the same people guess whose party had zero attendees then for valentine's day my mom encouraged me to send my ex friend mean anonymous valentines that only resulted in me getting in trouble because obviously my ex friend knew who sent them and told on me so yeah don't do that stuff

my son was kinda on the other side of this he met a kid in kindergarten and they hit it off really well i started noticing around th and th grade that he didn’t talk about him much and he really only saw him at scouts this boy is on the spectrum and super smart and sweet i said something to his mom who i’m good friends with and she explained that the reason they got along so well when they were younger was because they had the same interests as my son got older he changed but his friend didn’t mature at the same rate i encourage him to take time to hang out with him at school or eat lunch with him i work with adults with disabilities so i’m hyper aware of people that seem “different” on the outside my mom also worked in that field so i was always around that population because of that i try really hard to teach the same things my mom taught me to my son i hope he gets it i don’t really have advice but i just hope that the mom of that kid encourages him the way i encourage my son

it's hard but unfortunately there isn't much you can do at this age my son is he's extroverted with a boatload of friends but he recently had to cut ties with one of his best friends he was best friends with these two boys since he was years old and they were so close they played at a local park together everyday and we called them the three amigos he's still good friends with one but the other has gotten into experimenting with drugs and alcohol recently my son doesn't approve and doesn't want to be around that he knows it's what he has to do and is the one breaking off the friendship but it's still tough and my son already has some loss issues i let him know that i'm here if he wants to talk and he often takes me up on that he has friends over everyday after practice and has a group of friends sleeping over tonight and i know that helps i would try getting him involved in sports or an activity to try and make more friends it doesn't replace the loss but it's harder to lose your only friend than it is to lose one friend my daughter lost a large group of friends in th grade when she quit dance and it was really hard on her to not really have anyone friends she had for a decade were no longer inviting her over she has joined her school cross country and robotics teams and is doing theater as a freshman this year she has a solid group of friends and has them over for board game nights regularly it's hard to watch but there isn't anything for you to do other than be supportive and encourage other friendships
my son was the weird kid from k th grade or so in high school things got better and now that he’s in college he seems to be doing very well socially it took a long time though

as a parent myself and someone who works with kids i see many different types of kids and situations and many times it comes down to finding the ones similar to you just like with adults not everyone meshes well or has similar traits there are many kids that randomly call out words or sounds from video games and the others that might see those kids as weird some that are really loud and some that are quiet some that are full of energy and some that barely exude any etc not sure your son's age but as they get older personalities develop more what used to be a situation where everyone could run around and pretend and play together is now becoming a who has similar interests and finds each other's company enjoyable if his friend isn't the kind of guy who randomly calls out video game references and finds that annoying in a friend that might not be the type of friend your son should have i hate to say that but people need to feel the friends they have and the people they're around like them and the way they are and vice versa i'm going through similar things as my son will be soon who tends to be a loud silly guy often who he himself randomly calls out references and i can tell what kids like that about him and are like that too and what ones are annoyed by that obviously the latter aren't going to be good friend material for his personality i'm trying to encourage him to not play with those who aren't nice to him basically those who would make someone feel bad for being who they are which unfortunately comes up everyone needs to find people they click with and if it means it's not that one friend from nd grade so be it he'll find the ones who accept him for him and are like him and enjoy his company

i say things like “in this house family we speak kindly to each other when you are ready to talk to me like i’m talking you calm kind patient i’m ready to hear you ” “the family rule is we use inside voices and respectful language i’m not going to allow you to speak to me like that so i am going to go do laundry nap read until you’re ready to talk about this appropriately ” “i won’t let you scream at your sibling i’m going to have you spend time in the backyard where you are free to be loud however your language must me appropriate if you begin to scream inappropriate things the consequences are ” so i explain what is not acceptable and what i won’t put up with then i finish with what i will accept i’m happy to negotiate or plan consequences ahead of time before they are in trouble now when the consequences land they know they played a role in it i will not over explain or justify consequences after their unwanted behavior i use as few words as possible while remaining calm and pleasant albeit serious in my response [mary van geffen] on instagram has a been a great resource for me in raising stubborn strong smart energetic little girls that she calls “spicy”

my yo went through something similar a few months ago it seems to ebb and flow she has type diabetes and as part of her care team she has a psychologist that we work with to help her with her mental health lots of teaching through example and checking in with her so my advice is this the next time this happens where you can see her mood turning difficult and disrespectful take a step back and ask her is everything okay if she gets defensive or rude shoot her down calmly explaining that you don't want to fight point out that she seems stressed because more often than not in my experience whatever is causing her stress or mood usually has nothing to do with me at all and say you're just checking in and you're there if she needs to talk see if she wants a hug this tactic works almost every time for me and it teaches my daughter that she can come to me for support in times where things are getting the better of her it shows her that we can tackle these problems together and that there's no shame in having her feelings and acknowledging them we try to find proactive solutions to whatever is bothering her which is a great tool for her to learn it also heads off a lot of arguments at the pass so then when things are a bit calmer i can talk to her about the value of being able to speak to each other with respect and understanding obviously this isn't foolproof and we've had plenty of arguments and she can be a brat when she wants but it's a great way to handle difficult moments and not only with kids i've found lol hope this helps

at around kids realize that they don't have to obey parents or other authority figures just because everything must have a reason the logic behind every rule has to be explained they start to see all the connections and how society works now they start to be aware of the basics of economics politics laws etc you have to earn back your kid's respect and slowly convince her that you are looking out for her and your goal is to ensure that she is a productive and well liked member of society when she grows up and not simply to boss her around >i am trying to be rational with her and telling her that her behavior is rude and horrible but she turns it back on me good job keep it up further explain to her calmly that her behavior makes you feel angry and upset at her and that makes it harder for you to say yes to her when she wants something >is this a phase or is this how it's going to be from now on i think it's a long phase that lasts a year or so if you're lucky and or do a good job your kid will become more responsible and better understand why she has to put in effort at academics and chores etc and then the next bump in the road will be the teenage years

absolutely they know who they can express their emotions and frustrations with safely it’s a tactic so long as it works it shouldn’t work then it won’t be a tactic it’ll just be a means to express their big emotions we want to teach our kids other ways of self expression which we can do by modeling which is also where most of us fail going into war will only render losses in the long term sacrificing bits from the relationship the war is internal within ourselves putting aside our pain and ego in the most heated situations and then only when the child is ready and available to listen will we make our statement about what has happened and what is not tolerated and why how to get your child attuned so you can speak well the easiest trick is to give them food they can’t be too pissed and eat simultaneously of course not immediately after they misbehave or something… children don’t usually just misbehave consistently i mean having an independent todd wanting everything at the same time not being able to say what it is that they want and being all enraged about it isn’t misbehavior — it’s called toddlerhood so as will all ages there are some behaviors that are more or less representative of the developmental phase of the child just something to take in mind

if we deprive them they won't be able to function in the real world i tried with a few of my older kids and it led them to over indulge once they finally had unrestricted access yes it only happens with screens i'm teaching them to be mindful of their other activities like chores sleep bathing and being ready for school the next day obviously they need to be able to regulate their own little minds and bodies i failed my older kids by taking away the chance to learn to regulate at home now i have teenagers that ask me to cut their social media off for a day or two occasionally because they feel overwhelmed and want to reset they remember losing screen time for behavior when they were younger they remember feeling peaceful without it and now they seek out breaks on their own i'm not saying any of this is easy or fun or that there aren't times i have to take the router to bed with me i'm saying consistency and fairness on my part toward them coupled with weathering the torrent of their big feelings in the moment has worked best for everyone

comforting kids video games let me start by saying that i f do not care about video games i appreciate them as a form of art but playing them has just never made much sense to me i’m not particularly competitive and just don’t find them enjoyable that said my ex is an avid gamer and my son is now too during the week my son is with me my husband and my mom none of us play video games my son being probably isn’t the best gamer in the world and naturally he gets really upset when he loses a game or perceives that someone has “attacked” him he mostly plays roblox if that’s relevant the problem is that when he gets upset about something in the game i have no idea how to help or comfort him if this issue—losing a game something “unfair” happening—were to happen in real life i feel prepared to handle that i’m a teacher and talk kids through difficult experiences all the time but pretty much always in situations where we can observe the other party’s contributions and root our discussions in empathy and boundaries in terms of the game i have no idea who the other players are what their motivations are other than winning and just generally don’t have much to say besides “that sounds frustrating i’m sorry buddy maybe we should take a break from the game ” generally he shoots that idea down wipes his tears and gets back to the game every now and then he’ll come for a cuddle before doing the same i also don’t know if this level of emotion around a game is “normal” or if it signifies that maybe he shouldn’t be allowed to play them anymore he’s not throwing things or screaming in anger but he cries a lot losing is a part of life so i don’t think it’s bad necessarily to practice losing i just don’t know how to support him better or when enough is enough gamer parents out there—help please

how does your son display his anger at these games two of my kids have been in sports and they are big sore losers i had to learn to just let them have their emotions as long as they aren’t being destructive yelling cursing hitting etc kids are learning emotional regulation so it can be tough for them to get a blow like a loss and not get upset i think you’re doing a great job in encouraging him to maybe take or break and for validating his feelings the fact that he gets back on the game afterwards is great sounds like a resilient little guy

when you hear him getting frustrated start watching what he’s doing when he loses “that looks hard that x thing you did looked cool though is that hard to do in this game you’ll get it because your good ” everyone needs to hear they’re awesome even when they’re losing sometimes hell i need it on my bad mom days when i feel like i’m not doing anything right you don’t suck at what you’re doing you’re just having a rough run 🤷‍♀️
i say “video games are supposed to be fun if you’re not having fun i’m going to turn it off” and that usually squashes the anger

i am educator parent gamer and pivoting into a career in educational software design imo is young for solo video game playing particularly if it’s an action game action games are the genre of game that test and strengthen hand eye coordination spacial reasoning and reaction time this is one of the oldest most popular and most anxiety inducing game genres playing with a parent is different and i think central to you issue it sounds like you son and his father have a play based bond whether it’s sports cards board games or video games play is a wonderful foundation for a relationship with a child it can also set expectations in a child that can confuse them when they’re not met in this case i suspect your son is not responding to the game itself but rather confusion over why you’re not displaying interest and understanding please don’t take this as a criticism of you everyone plays in their own way and it’s all good but the fact that you’re here asking the question shows that even though you don’t have the answers about the specific game you still want to answer your son’s needs i suggest play find your own way to play with him maybe you can draw him into your world and how you play how do you play think hard about that and how you can share your own way of playing with your son maybe you’ll be the one who has to budge and pick up a controller the good news is that you’ll find that as a year old female you are the demographic that the game industry want the most you belong to a fast growing demographic of game players and the market is flooded with games that marketers think you’ll like you may find other types of video games that you can bond with your son over i recommend the “point and click” adventure game genre these games are based on story frequently feature kid friendly graphics and characters and never put players in high pressure stressful situations they’re absolutely wonderful for side by side kid parent play talking through the character choices and story logic can be incredibly fun good luck i’m passionate about bringing kids and their adults closer together with games so i hope this helps if you’d like more recommendations or have questions i’d love to talk more

i would honestly like to play minecraft but there is a mental block for me that’s hard to explain i have trouble with coordination between my mind and game controls of any sort the closest i’ve ever been to making sense of the controls with any kind of video game was a vr situation like if i can physically act out what i want the character to do games are really fun otherwise i get a massive headache and the spins just trying to get from move forward —> use legs and walk to move forward —> use fingers to press this button it sounds crazy but it all comes down to being on the spectrum and generally having poor spatial reasoning 🤣 thankfully my little guy has a ton of very actively involved adults in his life with a wide variety of skills and interests he knows dad and uncle dan are the video game people stepdad is the sports and cartoons guy grandma is complex lego sets and puzzles and mom is in the garden or out in the tool shed

meaningful activities with a year old kid hello my aunt died a few weeks ago and she left us with her year old son my cousin my uncle can't spend too much time with my cousin his son because he's busy with his business and he's also grieving my aunt's death a week ago my grandmother my uncle's mother also died so my uncle is a bit of an emotional wreck but he does try to spend quality time with my cousin every now and then my cousin has alternative caregivers one is a relative of ours but sometimes she's busy with household chores she can't give her full attention to my cousin the other caregiver is my other aunt who's my uncle's sister she occasionally plays with my cousin but because she's working from home she can't give her attention to my cousin oftentimes my cousin would videocall me or his cousins in his mom's side whenever i'm not doing household chores or not working from home i'd give him my full attention he's very clingy and whenever i visit their house and i have to go home afterwards he'd block my way and doesn't want me to go home i know he misses his mom so much and he knows his mom is never coming back the pandemic made it even worse for kids like him since he can't be with his playmates of his age i'm he's most of the time i'd just watch him play roblox or minecraft sometimes we'd watch youtube videos together can you guys suggest other meaningful activities that we can bond over other than youtube or computer games he's coming over to our house sometime this week and to be honest i don't know what activities can be done together with him we can just stick with the usual roblox minecraft or youtube but i know how short a kid's attention span can be thanks in advance 😁

so my mom is my year olds best friend and she lives hours away they really bonded this year when he would video call her during the hours i was working from home he takes her around on his ipad and stands her up and then he does things he plays lego or on the swings or whatever they talk for hours at a time she doesn't just watch though she often pretends to be an announcer when he's being physical this is it ladies and gentleman x is trying to jump from the couch to the chair can he do it will he survive and he eats it up if he's doing lego she might ask what he's building and then look up facts about something he mentions she'll shower him with info about megalodon while he's building one from lego she sings him songs or gives him suggestions of songs to ask alexa to play then watches him dance party she buys two of some coloring books and she'll color with him on the same page then they compare in the end for my son it is about having someone care what he's doing and give him that undivided attention she doesn't pepper him with questions she participates in his play she becomes a part of his world and for a kiddo who spends most of his time in someone elses world that is absolutely huge for him i hope that helps

year old son loves to pretend with guns knives what to do so my son loves playing army men and loves pretending hes shooting and kniving bad guys well some times he does get a little carried away well my wife and mother in law went on a trip away for several days and i guess he was getting more carried away than usual and now the mil thinks hes going to grow up to shoot up schools and wants everything tied to guns taken away he has nerf gus army men gi joe figures and plays some army games on roblox all that is to be taken away and my wife is siding with the mil my concern is this isn't addressing the problem and just taking everything away isnt going to help him understand what is happening he has adhd and slight autism so im concerned taking everything away will do more harm than good because he doesnt understand fully and cant comprehend why hes having everything he enjoys being taken away im looking for some advise and guidance is my way of thinking wrong or should we be taking evertything away

i didn't want my kid to grow up with gun play so i didn't buy any for him when he was younger turns out he used sticks or his fingers so yeah i did give in with nerf guns because it was a losing battle and he was missing out of fun play with his friends for no reason i think it's important to have an age appropriate convo that stresses that this is play and not real also think it's important to teach kids about the differences between toy guns and an actual real gun what to do if he's somewhere and stumbles across a real gun what to do if one of his friends is playing with a real gun what kind of carnage a real gun can do etc but also i think mil is being a bit dramatic

what does his therapist psychiatrist and doctor say on the subject surely a child officially diagnosed with *both* asd and adhd has a small team including an in school support person so what do the professionals in his life recommend who handles his iep in school i am sure they will have some feedback

talk to his team of course but this isn't something i would be to worried about does he understand real vs pretend my yr old kid and my brother and his friends growing up were all super into guns and knives good guys and bad guys we had all the toys and when toy guns weren't around sticks or whatever became guns my child was always making bombs and such but has stopped at this point for different things we all learned gun safety at appropriate ages too as we had guns in the house or in my kids case grandparents house no one grew up violent heck no one even hunts it was pretend play

i'd explain to the mil that people don't shoot up schools because they love guns and knives they are usually young men teens that are extremely depressed have been bullied hate the cruel unfairness of the world and want revenge and notoriety as long as you concentrate on growing a loved happy empatheitc emotionally stable child then the chances of him becoming a school shooter are extreamly small

children learn to control and meditate strong negative emotions like anger and aggression through play our experience in trying to bring our preschool's no guns rule home we thought child needed consistency is that child lost a valuable outlet for learning and expression of his feelings instead of pretend aggression he became more aggressive for real we backtracked fast i stead of a no guns rule we taught a lot of vocabulary for negative feelings encouraged expression and emphasized the difference between real and pretend and respect for intuitive rules force allowed in self defense but not otherwise child turned out well and is not violent
